characters: CAUSE I SAID SO, THAT'S WHY, NOW GET OUT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Palms sway ... the sun washes everything in yellow ... ca motor down either side of the landscaped median ... the c of mockingbirds mingle with the BLIP BLIP of car alarms. ON THE SIDEWALK, a SKATEBOARD CA-LUNKS down the sidewalk, past the foot traffic of Southern Californians: flip-flop Doc Marten's, Rollerblades, Nikes ... then, in the middle this pedestrian normalcy, a pair of IMPOSSIBLY HIGH SPIKE HEELED PUMPS struts out of a shop.  So high it hurts to l at them.  As the shoes leave frame, we TILT UP and see they're leaving a 99-cent store. As the Pumps turn and head up the street, we see they are connected to a pair of IMPOSSIBLY LONG, SHAPELY LEGS. Eveready legs -- they just keep going and going. They saunter past two BUSINESSMEN on a lunch break.  The pause and glance as men tend to when they see a beautiful woman.  In fact, everyone this woman passes lets their ey rest on her a microsecond longer than usual. - Two SKATEBOARDERS note the STRETCHY MICRO-MINI skimming tops of her thighs. - A MAILMAN spots the BIG, DARK SUNGLASSES tucked into a MOUNTAIN OF BIG, BLOND HAIR. - A PRE-TEEN GIRL glimpses the PLUNGING NECKLINE of the TIGHT, BRIGHT RED MIDRIFF-BARING BUSTIER. It isn't until she rounds the corner at the end of the bl that we see her entire figure and appreciate why everyone so goggle-eyed.  Eye-catching is an understatement.  All those folks who say Barbie's proportions are unrealistic obviously never met ERIN BROCKOVICH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A side street.  No pedestrians, just parked cars.  A PARK TICKET flaps under the wiper of an old Hyundai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck. Even when she talks dirty, there's a heartland goodness t her voice.  Like Kansas corn fields swaying in the breeze As she grabs the ticket from the windshield, her sunglass accidentally CLATTER to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. When she picks them up, a fingernail snags on the pavemen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn it. She tends to the nail as she opens her car door and gets

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hyundai starts it up, signals.  Then, just as it pull slowly out into the street, a JAGUAR barrels around the corner, accelerating out of the turn, and rams into the s of Erin's car, sending it CAREENING into the median.  It SMASHES into a foot-thick lightpost.  And stops. EXT. MASRY & VITITOE - DAY A boring building on a boring block in the Valley, surrou by strip malls.  Definitely not where the power lawyers w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Mr. Masry.  How you doing today? INT. MASRY & VITITOE, RECEPTION - DAY Generic.  Cottage cheese ceilings, motel art.  A sign ove the reception desk reads: MASRY & VITITOE, ATTORNEYS ED MASRY, senior partner, slumps by ROSALIND, his chipper receptionist, with a cup of coffee in his hand.  He's in mid-50's, compact and -- even though it's only 9 AM -- already rumpled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ask that on Mondays, Rosalind. Whatever passion he once had for the personal injury law is his career has long since dissipated.  He trundles off toward his office. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, OUTSIDE ED'S OFFICE - DAY Ed's secretary BRENDA -- 50's, jaded, hates her job, but can you do? -- is on the phone when Ed rounds the corner. She puts the call on hold, turns to Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony Marvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus.  Who's responsible for his pain and suffering this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His dry cleaners.  You want him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?  What's this? He grabs a gift-wrapped bottle off her desk, reads the ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tequila.  From your drug dealer friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carlos isn't a friend; he's a client.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a low-life.  Speaking of which, that's your nine o'clock in there. Ed peers into his office.  It's a mess -- papers everywhe unopened mail.  Standing in the middle of the room is Eri in a teensy, leopard-print mini-dress.  As she jiggles a spike-heeled foot, everything about her shimmies glorious Except her head, which is held in place by a neck brace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa. (to Brenda)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remind me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin Brockovich.  Car accident.  Not her fault, she says. (sarcastic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she looks like such an honest girl, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't judge, Brenda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  Lap-dancers are people too. As Ed heads into his office, Brenda picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't find him, Tony.  We'll have to call you back. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, ED'S OFFICE - DAY Not an office that exudes authority, and Ed's blustery entrance only adds to the sense of chaos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin -- hi.  Sorry you had to wait.  Here, sit down, sit down. He clears a stack of papers off a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot. (as she sits)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you, I never thought just standing would take it out of me, but ever since that shithead hit me, it feels like my whole body's put together wrong. Ed gives her a look of pro-forma sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, you poor thing. (he sits)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, listen, you came to the right place. Whoever did this to you made one hell of a mistake, and you and me, we're gonna make him pay for it. He takes out a pad and paper, gets ready to write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you tell me what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin is on the stand, wearing the most conservative thing owns: a red, form-fitting mini dress, telling her story t Ed, who's questioning her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was pulling out real slow, and out of nowhere, his Jaguar comes racing around the corner like a bat outta hell ... She glances at the defendant's table, where a DOCTOR sits nobly in surgical scrubs.  His WIFE and two beautiful KID are behind him.  A frigging Norman Rockwell painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They took some bone from my hip and put it in my neck.  I didn't have insurance, so I'm about seventeen thousand in debt right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... couldn't take painkillers cause they made me too groggy to take care of my kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Matthew's six, Katie's four, and Beth's just nine months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... just wanna be a good mom, a nice person, a decent citizen.  Just wanna take good care of my kids.  You know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (oh so moved)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin is still on the stand.  But now the doctor's lawyer questioning her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventeen thousand in debt.  Whew.  Is your ex-husband helping out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feigning shock)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's more than one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  There's two.  Why? Erin looks over at the jury.  The personification of conservative family values.  Oh, shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting defensive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... not like a career, cause I had my babies. But I woulda worked, for sure, if I didn't have this neck thing. Erin sees a juror staring judgmentally at her short hem. Erin gives it a tug, pulling it down a stitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  No doubt. Erin sees a few jurors share dubious glances.  Great.

dialogues.speaker: STILL LATER
dialogues.text: The defendant's lawyers is on the offensive.  Erin's star to feel the case slipping away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So.  You must've been feeling pretty desperate that afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your point? Ed shakes his head slightly to her -- don't get mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broke, three kids, no job.  A doctor in a Jaguar must've looked like a pretty good meal ticket. Erin sees jurors nodding almost imperceptibly in agreemen She's on a sinking ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Hey -- he hit me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He came tearing around the corner, out of control --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ER doctor who spends his days saving lives was the one out of control --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (erupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That asshole smashed in my fucking neck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to the courtroom flies open and Erin comes out, furious.  Ed follows her as she heads for the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open and shut?  Open and fucking shut?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you hadn't used profanity --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, please, it was long over by then.  God damn, he made me look like some cheap --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you the questions might get a little personal --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit.  You told me I'd get half a million dollars.  You told me I'd be set. Ed notices her ranting is starting to draw attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay -- let's try and settle down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Settle down?  I got 74 bucks to my name, Mr. Masry!  I can't afford to settle down! Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Erin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  Well, fuck you.  Sorry doesn't feed my kids. Erin turns away from him and heads for the stairway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shitty little house in a shitty part of Northbridge.  T Hyundai with a bashed-in side pulls up to the curb. Erin gets out, takes the mail from her mailbox, then head over to the equally grim house next door and rings the be A Hispanic woman in her 60's opens the door, holding a wh baby.  This is MRS. MORALES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Erin!  You're back so soon.  How was it? She hands Erin the baby.  It's BETH, Erin's 9-month old. Erin avoids the question by focusing on her baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, sweetie.  Were you a good girl?  Where are Matt and Katie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside with the sprinkler.  So it's good? The truth is too depressing to share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be fine, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ai, bueno.  Because I didn't want to tell you before, with your worries --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daughter, she's bought a big house with a room for me.  I'm going to move in with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're moving away?  When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, that's soon --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  But it's good for me.  Now I can help my daughter take care of my grandkids. And it's good for you, too.  Now you have money, you can find a good babysitter, huh? Not the old lady next door. Oh, God.  In Erin's arms, Beth starts to COUGH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin carries Beth up to her house.  As she nears her door she steps on a GIANT WATER BUG.  It crunches under her so

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh. Insult added to injury.  She heads up to the house, dragg her shoe, wiping off the bug guts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as dull inside.  Salvation Army furniture.  A lot of beige.  Erin's two older kids, MATTHEW (7) and KATIE (5) at the table.  Beth is in a baby seat.  Erin spoons some & Cheese onto their plates, trying to hide her worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like this part, it's all crusty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like the crust. Erin switches the plates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put your napkins in your laps and eat up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you're not eating? Cause there isn't enough food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mamma's gonna eat later. From her baby seat on the table, Beth COUGHS some more. Thick, sick-sounding coughs.  Erin looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go getting sick on me, baby.  Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shower and sink are both on full, filling the room wi STEAM.  Erin is seated with COUGHING, CRYING Beth on her trying to steam the illness out of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gonna be okay, sweetheart.  I promise. But her face doesn't look like she believes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt and Katie are messing around with a gumball machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin is holding Beth, wandering the aisles.  She stops at medicines, thinks for a long moment, then, hating herself glances to make sure no one's looking, and picks up a bot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a CUSTOMER steps away from the register, Erin steps up with the bottle in her hand and smiles at the CHECK-OUT L

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, remember me?  I was in yesterday.  Bought a whole mess of stuff?  Round about five?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, it's a zoo here at five.  I'm lucky if I even see a face, much less remember it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shoot, yeah, I guess that'd be tough. Well, listen, I meant to buy my baby here some medicine, and by the time I got home, I realized I'd bought the adult stuff by mistake.  And now, wouldn't you know, I can't find the receipt.  I was wondering -- could I maybe exchange it anyway ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin feeds Beth her medicine, feeling miserable about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just remember.  No matter what your Mamma does, lying and stealing is real bad.  I don't ever wanna hear you doing something like that ... On the table beside her sit the classifieds.  Row after r of want ads circled, then X-'d out in red.  A WATER BUG crawls across the edge of the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Cause there's no excuse for it, you hear me?  No excuse at all. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, ED'S OFFICE - DAY Midday.  Ed enters with a cup of coffee in his hand.  As heads to his desk, he trips on a box of files.  Coffee sloshes out of his cup, onto his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it! (calling out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenda! She pops her head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? He grabs a tissue, swabs his shirt, then kicks at the box

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is this doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's those files you asked for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean for you to leave them in the middle of the floor.  Jesus.  Look at me. What do I have this afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing you can't show up for with a stain. As Ed checks his reflection in the glass wall of his offi he notices, on the other side: ERIN, standing in the middle of the secretaries' area, in miniskirt and leather bustier, talking to MARIO, the firm mentally challenged office boy.  Mario heads away from he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's she doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Ed goes to his office door and waves Mario over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- Mario -- what's she doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She works here. Ed looks back at her -- what the hell? INT. MASRY & VITITOE, MAIN ROOM - DAY The support staff -- mostly middle-aged women -- are all stealing glances at Erin.  Ed comes up to her, all friend

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin!  How's it going? Up close, the wear and tear of worry show on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never called me back.  I left messages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did?  Wow, sorry about that. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Mario's a little not so bright.  He seems to think that you said --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's two things I can't stand, Mr. Masry. Being ignored, and being lied to.  You did both. Glances skitter between the secretaries -- get a load of this.  Ed lowers his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never lied.  I may have miscalculated -- that happens sometimes, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said things would be fine, and they're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about that.  Really.  But --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need pity.  I need a paycheck.  And I've looked, but when you've spent the last six years raising babies, it's real hard to convince someone to give you a job that pays worth a damn.  So I figure, since you're the one who said I was gonna be okay, you should be the one to hire me. Ed sees everyone watching him, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to help, Erin, but I'm sorry, I have a full staff right now, so -- He starts to escort her out, but she stays put.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit.  If you had a full staff, you'd have time to return your damn phone calls. She's backing him into a corner here.  He shifts gears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, look.  If you really want to apply for a job here, you can do it the way everyone else does.  Send in a rГ€sumГ€, make an --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not everyone else, Mr. Masry.  I'm someone you made promises to that you didn't deliver on.  I trusted you.  With my kids' well-being.  Now, I'm smart, and I'm hard- working, and I'll do anything.  But if you think I'm leaving here without a job, you got another thing coming. Ed glances around the room.  Not a whole lot of options h He looks back at Erin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No benefits. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, FILE ROOM - DAY A tight office lined with file cabinets and shelves.  ANN the humorless file clerk, is showing Erin around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... what we do in here is keep track of all the case files.  That way, at any time, we can find out a case's status -- where it is in the office, stuff like that.  We file 'em all here, alphabetically --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hell. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm dyslexic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a joke, right? Erin shakes her head, no.  Great, thinks Anna. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, MAIN ROOM - DAY As Anna shows Erin around the office, they pass JANE, the bitter office manager, and Brenda, at the coffee area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just last week, he told my sister we weren't hiring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your sister look like? INT. MASRY & VITITOE, ED'S OFFICE - NIGHT Ed is packing up his office.  Erin sticks her head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Masry? He turns, sees her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wondering -- could you tell me who I'd talk to about maybe getting an advance on my paycheck?  Just -- for the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane's the office manager.  She handles payroll and petty cash.  But she leaves early on Fridays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  Okay.  That's okay. Ed looks at her a moment, sees that it's far from okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, for Christ's sake ... He takes out his wallet, looks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I have is hundreds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wanna take your money, Mr. Masry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit, you don't. He slaps a hundred in her hand and leaves.  When he's gon she looks at the bill -- her life raft -- and gives it a great big kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin is at the door, taking Beth from the BABYSITTER, a shabby, unkempt-looking woman in her 40's.  Katie and Mat pull on their backpacks and troop out of the sitter's hou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin is leaving the store, carrying Beth in one arm and a of groceries in the other.  Katie and Matt are each carry a bag of groceries as well.  They are all singing and mov with the jaunty step of the newly carefree.  Katie spots flower display outside the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy, can I get a flower?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, you can get a whole big bunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small room with Salvation Army furniture.  A BUNCH OF DAISIES is propped in a Ragu jar on Katie's bedside table Matt and Katie are asleep in bed.  Erin looks down at the smiles, then kisses them good-night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin comes out of the bedroom and softly closes the door. But just as the handle clicks into place, the house is fi with the DEAFENING ROAR of a MOTORCYCLE, REVVING and REVV It sounds as if it's gonna drive through the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin steps out onto her front stoop and looks over at wha used to be Mrs. Morales's house.  A few MOTORCYCLES are parked on the lawn; A FEW BIKERS are drinking beer on the stoop; and one asshole is on his bike, REVVING HIS ENGINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! But of course he can't hear her.  She walks over to him, stands right in his line of vision.

dialogues.speaker: HEY
dialogues.text: He sees her and kills the engine.  Everything about GEORG HALABY is tough -- his denim, his leather, his bike, his hair.  Everything but his eyes, which twinkle like Santa'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hello to you, darlin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell do you think you're doing, making all that Goddamn noise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just introducing myself to the neighbors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm the neighbors.  There, now we're introduced, so you can shut the fuck up. The guys on the porch chuckle.  Erin turns and starts bac her house.  George hops off his bike and follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooh, now, see, if I'da known there was a beautiful woman next door, I'da done this different.  Let's start over.  My name's George.  What's yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just think of me as the person next door who likes it quiet, and we'll get along fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, don't be like that.  Tell you what. How about if I take you out on a date to apologize for my rudeness? Erin shakes her head in disbelief and keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.  Gimme your number, I'll call you up proper and ask you out and everything. She stops at her porch, turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want my number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which number do you want, George?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got more than one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, yeah.  I got numbers coming out of my ears.  Like, for instance, ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  That's one of my numbers.  It's how many months old my little girl is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a little girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Sexy, huh?  And here's another: five. That's how old my other daughter is.  Seven is my son's age.  Two is how many times I been married and divorced.  You getting all this?  16 is the number of dollars in my bank account.  454-3943 is my phone number. And with all the other numbers I gave you, I'm guessing zero is the number of times you're gonna call it. She turns and heads inside.  He calls out after her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell do you know your bank balance right off the top of your head like that? See, that impresses me. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, RECEPTION AREA - DAY Morning.  Erin walks in, wearing her usual garb.  She pas the coffee area, where Jane, Brenda, and Anna are milling Brenda sees her, gives Anna a nudge.  They both check out short hem.  Anna nudges Jane, who looks as well.  Erin glances over just in time to see all three of them starin her judgementally.  She stops in her tracks and stares ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'all got something you wanna discuss? The women go back to stirring their coffees.  Erin walks INT. MASRY & VITITOE, ED'S OFFICE - DAY Ed is walking into his office with a coffee cup in his ha when he trips over the same box of files again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it! (calling out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenda! (no answer)

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: INT. MASRY & VITITOE, FILE ROOM - DAY Erin is alone, filing as she talks on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long's she been crying like that? ... Well, she's got that tooth coming in -- Ed appears in the door, carrying the box of files.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give her a cold washcloth to suck on -- (sees Ed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta go -- there's a clean one in that bag -- I'll check back in a bit. (hangs up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.  My kid --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Anna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out to lunch with the girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  Huh. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, look, I got this file I need valued. Real estate thing.  A lady has some property next to a PG&E plant that PG&E wants to buy. I need to know what to ask for it. He plunks the box of files on her desk.  She stares at it with no idea of how to go about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  Okay. He sees her staring at the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do know how to do that, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  I got it.  No problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Ed heads out, but pauses before leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you're not at lunch with the girls? You're a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'm not the right kind. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, FILE ROOM - NIGHT Erin is at her desk, staring bewildered at the files from box Ed gave her, which are now spread across her desktop. She sees Anna packing up her things, to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna?  With this real-estate valuing stuff - - could you remind me, cause I'm a little confused about how exactly we do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin, you've been here three weeks.  If you don't know how to do your job by now, I am not about to do it for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie and Matt are running up to the house.  Erin follows toting Beth under one arm and the box of documents under other.  She steps on another water bug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh. As she wipes the bug guts off the bottom of her shoe:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, neighbor, wanna beer? She spots George on his stoop, with a six-pack beside him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon.  I bought 'em for you, to make up for that night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Return 'em.  Maybe you'll get your money back. He gets up and follows her to her house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, why're you giving me such a hard time? I'm just trying to be a good neighbor. Erin turns to him.  The kids are waiting at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a good neighbor, George.  She was 60 and Mexican and she watched my kids for free.  Something tells me you're not gonna be able to measure up to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need help with your kids?  I could probably do that. George reaches out and grabs the box from under her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna leave my kids with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause I don't even know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and whose fault is that? He's got a point there.  After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, you got so many friends in this world, you don't have use for one more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is on the floor with Matt and Katie, playing War. Katie points to the Harley emblem on his leather jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that stand for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's for Harley Davidson.  The best damn motorcycle ever made. Erin comes in from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if I catch either of you anywhere near one, I'll knock you silly.  Go on to bed, now -- I'll come tuck you in in a minute. They get up ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night. ... and head into bed.  George starts cleaning up the car

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great kids. Erin bends down to help him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  I'm probably ruining them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm never here.  I gotta leave 'em with this weird sitter all afternoon who costs a fortune and smells like chicken fat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was serious before, you know.  If you need someone to keep an eye on them -- after school or something -- I don't have a job now, so I'm around in the afternoons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.  Another deadbeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a deadbeat.  I work when I need to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  And what do you do the rest of the time, live off your trust fund?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do construction, which pays real good. And I make it last by living cheap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a little laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope that's not supposed to impress me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you this hard on everyone who tries to help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a while.  Maybe I'm just out of practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then lemme remind you, the polite thing is to say, thank you, that's a real nice offer, I don't mind taking you up on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why in the hell would you want to watch my kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause I like kids.  I like hanging out with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. She starts cleaning up the cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.  I like how they keep it all simple, you know?  They don't get all complicated about life, like grown-ups do.  A bicycle and an ice cream cone -- boom, done, they're happy. Erin thinks about the offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're around every afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup.  Usually working on my bike. (she's tempted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No big deal.  If it doesn't work out, you can send 'em back to the chicken fat lady. Tempting.  Erin looks him over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't gonna get you laid, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we'll just see about that, won't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wee hours.  Erin's in a t-shirt, sitting on her mattr on the floor.  The paperwork from the box is now spread a over the floor around her.  She's reading a letter.

dialogues.speaker: THE LETTER
dialogues.text: It's from PG&E, to Donna and Peter Irving.  We see th phrases, "purchase your house ...", "fair market value ..

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER DOCUMENT
dialogues.text: It's a list of comparable house sales in the area.  Owner cost; owner, cost.  Every house is in the $65,000 range. From another room, she hears the sound of BETH CRYING.  S reading the file, Erin gets up and goes into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still reading, Erin gets Beth out of her crib.  Beth quie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin lies down on the mattress and rests Beth on her ches She sets down the file she was reading and picks up anoth

dialogues.speaker: THE FILE
dialogues.text: It contains a letter from a Dr. Howard Reeves.  The first paragraph contains the phrase "... medical examination of Donna and Peter Irving ..." Toward the end of the letter, there are two columns.  One headed: "IN RANGE".  The other: "OUT OF RANGE".  Under th head appear the following: "lymphocytes, T-lymphocytes, natural killer cells, T Helpers, T8 suppresser cells". Erin stares at it, confused. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, COFFEE AREA - DAY Erin is talking to Jane, who's pouring herself coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was in this real estate file I'm valuing. And -- see, I know they're the medical records from the people selling the house -- but it talks about things like lymphocytes and T8 suppressers. Erin sees Ed pass behind Jane.  She lowers her voice, so won't see her asking for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, it's not a problem or anything, but -- I'm just a little unclear on what those things are.  I thought maybe you'd know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I look like, Erin?  A library? And Jane walks away with her coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Large.  Looming.  Very establishment.  Through the window we see Erin at the desk, talking to a LIBRARIAN.  She has file in her hands.  Over this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masry & Vititoe, can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Rosalind, this is Erin.  Brockovich. From the file room?  I was wondering if you could tell Mr. Masry that I'm following up on that real estate thing out of the office. The librarian gives her directions to somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smaller, but still establishment.  Erin's Hyundai pulls i the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin is at the reference desk, eating a candy bar while s talks to the LIBRARIAN.  He checks something on the compu A couple of WHITE-COATED MEDICAL STUDENTS pass her, doubl taking.  They don't see many like her around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long, academic hallway lit by fluorescents.  Erin gets an elevator and heads down the hall.  She finds a door wi nameplate that reads "Jim Paulsen, Epidemiology" and KNOC The door opens and DR. JIM PAULSEN appears.  He's a class scientist: unruly hair, thick glasses.  Nothing like Erin ever shown up at his door.  He reels at the sight of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Paulsen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Erin Brockovich.  I was just over in the library there, asking a mess of questions about -- I guess they call it epidemiology? -- and the fella there told me to find you, cause you know all about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspicious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a joke?  Did Baxter put you up to this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Baxter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did, didn't he?  Baxter! BAXTER, another scientist, leans out of a door down the h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Baxter and Erin look at each other.  No recognition, of course.  Paulsen is immediately embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one put me up to anything.  I was just hoping I could ask you a couple questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mortified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course!  Oh, gosh, of course --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orderly chaos.  Dr. Paulsen, still recovering, has Erin's file in his hands.  Erin is sitting across from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, look, there isn't a ton of information here, but from what there is, I'd say that these two people here -- what are their names?  Shanna and Ashley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, I guess those are the kids --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've both got some immune system problem. Can't say what from, whether it's viral or genetic or what, but something's wrong.  And these guys -- Donna and Peter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their parents, I'm pretty sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, from what this stuff says, I'd say they both have some form of cancer. Wow.  That's more serious than Erin was expecting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON THE FILE on the kitchen counter.  The Irvings' p number is written on the front.  A PHONE IS RINGING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa!  Easy, easy, easy -- WIDEN to see Erin, phone to her ear, grabbing a carton of juice from Matt and Katie, who are fighting over it at th table.  Just as she takes it from them, the phone picks u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi!  You've reached the Irvings.  Leave a message and we'll get back to you just as soon as we can.  Bye-bye. BEEP.  Erin thinks a bit, then hangs up and looks at the file.  Scrawled on the cover is the Irvings' address, in Hinkley, California.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beat-up old Hyundai heads east out of L.A.  DISCO MUS blares from its speakers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a dry, desolate part of California.  No downtown, community.  Just tract after tract of arid farmland, with small, bland, unprotected ranch home cropping up out of t landscape like occasional tombstones. A beat-up old sign on the road reads: "HINKLEY, CA.  POP: but the  corner where the number would be has broken off. As a gust of wind lifts dust from the fields, Erin turns Community Boulevard, the main road that cuts through Hink

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin looks around.  The house she's passing has been raze A heap of lumber and wires in the middle of the property. As she checks the piece of paper with Donna's address, sh drives by the PG&E COMPRESSOR STATION, a massive gray structure of pipes, chimneys and ladders, set way back fr the road.  Erin passes it without noticing it. She stops at an intersection.  The house on the corner ha been boarded up with plywood.  Erin notices it -- depress -- then turns the corner onto Donna's street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A generic ranch home standing all alone in the middle of nothing.  There's a pool out back and a chain link fence hugging the property.  No landscaping.  Dull, but clean. few BOTTLES OF SPRING WATER wait by the door. The Hyundai pulls into the driveway and stops.  Erin gets out.  As she heads up to the door, her spike heels sink i the dirt.  She rings the bell.  It has a melody chime. DONNA IRVING opens the door.  She's 35, petite, with a scrappy, high-strung manner.  She's wearing tight jeans, her dark curls are piled on top of her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.  Donna Irving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Erin Brockovich, from Masry & Vititoe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, no.  I hate lawyers.  I just work for them.  You got a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is furnished with little money, but lots of car Erin's on a plaid couch, in a sea of needlepoint pillows. Out back, two GIRLS, ages 9 and 11, are playing in a pool

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a real nice place you got here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it oughta be, with all the work I put into it. She comes out from the kitchen with a tray of iced tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I added air conditioning, put in the pool, made all those pillows by hand ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  I should learn to do stuff like that. They make the place feel real homey. Donna corrects the positioning on a couple of pillows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  I think so too.  That's why I'm being such a stickler on this house price thing.  I don't mean to be a pain in PG&E's backside, especially after all they've done for Hinkley, but I look around here and I think, if they want this place, they're gonna have to pay for it.  And I don't just mean pay for the house; I'd like them to pay me for the trouble of starting over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause first you gotta move, then there's decorating, and if the windows aren't the same size, you know -- you're making all new curtains.  Honest to God, I don't know if I have the energy.  You know, I've been sick. Me and Peter both have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm real glad you brought that up.  I was going through your file here, and I ran into these medical records.  They kinda surprised me -- This would be the perfect opportunity for many to get sel pitying.  But not Donna.  Life's handed her a shitload of lemons, and darned if she hasn't made a shitload of lemon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  They're more than a bit unusual. See, two years ago, Pete got Hodgkin's disease.  That's a kind of cancer --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm real sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  It's in remission now, thank the Lord, but you never know.  And then while that's going on, I end up having to have a hysterectomy.  Plus a whole mess of lumps removed from my breasts.  All benign so far, but still, no matter how positive you stay, an operation can still take it out of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll say.  Holy moley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the whole idea of selling the house -- don't get me wrong, I'd be glad to move to some better place, but if they aren't gonna pay us properly, I just don't see the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I can see that. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess the only thing that confused me is - - not that your medical problems aren't important, but -- how come the files about them are in with all the real estate stuff? Donna tops off their iced teas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding?  With how our lives are, if I start subdividing files, I'll be sunk.  I just kept all PG&E correspondence in one place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, but -- I'm sorry, I don't see why you were corresponding with PG&E about it in the first place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they paid for the doctor's visit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet.  Paid for a check-up for the whole family.  And not like with insurance where you pay, then wait a year to be reimbursed, either.  They just took care of it.  Just like that.  We never even saw a bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.  Why would they do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause of the chromium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chromium.  Well, that's what kicked this whole thing off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON A BOX, with "CHROM INFO" scrawled on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PG&E came around a few years ago, told us they put chromium in our well by mistake. And since we shouldn't have to drink it if we don't want to, they gave us free spring water and offered to buy our house. WIDEN to see Donna pulling the box down into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's chromium?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a chemical they used over at that compressor station up the road there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hell, maybe that's why you all have been so sick --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought the same thing, right off the bat. That's why we went to see the doctor.  But hunh-uh.  Turns out one's got nothing to do with the other. She rifles through the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the info they gave us.  You'll see if you look through it, chromium's good for you.  When I saw what they charged for it at the health-food stores, I about fainted. She hands Erin a printed fact sheet.  Erin scans it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems like an awful big coincidence -- your water being messed with and you being so sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not around here.  This is a rough part of the world.  Hard times, not a lot of money, not a lot of luck. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a challenge, staying healthy in a town like this.  Heck, even our dogs up and die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin's driving away from Donna's house.  A street lamp th light on the box of chromium documents in the passenger s She gets to an intersection and looks across the street a the massive COMPRESSOR STATION.  Six stories high, lit up like a Christmas tree, with all sizes of PIPES criss-cros the outside and GIANT COOLING TOWERS sticking up out of i Far more massive than anything else in town, it looms ove the horizon like the Capitol in D.C. or St. Peter's in Ro Erin takes a long look at the compressor station, then tu onto Community Boulevard and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin is holding Beth, making her a bottle, when she hears NOISES coming from outside.  She follows them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin opens the door to find George attaching bars to her windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better safe than sorry. She shakes her head, amused by his persistence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want some coffee, George?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George follows Erin in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna put a dead bolt on your front door, too.  This isn't exactly the safest neighborhood in the world, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for reminding me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess we get what we pay for, huh? Erin pours him some coffee, hands it to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think it could make you sick, living in a place like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? George settles in, helps himself to sugar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was talking to this lady -- she and her husband both got cancer, and she thinks it's cause they live in a bad neighborhood.  You think that's possible?  That living in a bad neighborhood could give you cancer? George laughs a little at the thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I hope not.  You got enough damn problems. But Erin's still mulling it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin clips down the block in short-shorts and high-heeled boots.  Up ahead a few of DOWN-ON-THEIR-LUCK MEN are out stoop, drinking their breakfast.  Erin approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, y'all -- how you doing today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hangin' in, baby.  How about yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay, I'm just fine.  I was wondering -- could I maybe ask you a couple questions? She settles down on the stoop with them for a chat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Paulsen and Erin are sitting, talking.  He's thrilled have her back in his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and when I realized our area's just as bad as Hinkley, I thought maybe my neighbors are all sick too.  So I went and asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did? Erin digs a pad of paper out of her bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.  Spent the last few days knocking on doors.  And you know what?  They're not. (reads from the pad)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, they got problems, but none of this cancer stuff.  And their pets are fine.  So I don't know -- I just can't shake the feeling that it wasn't no multivitamin they put in the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you're talking about contamination, you're getting out of my area of expertise. Let me give you the name of a toxicologist friend of mine over at USC. Paulsen reaches for a notepad, scrawls on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paulsen is seeing Erin out of his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta say, Erin -- first time I saw you, I did not peg you as the kind to go off and conduct her own epidemiological study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go telling anyone.  It'll ruin my reputation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin towers over DAVID FRANKEL as she walks across campus with him.  He's the grittier variety of scientist: Patago Birkenstocks, bushy beard.  He's as dry as dust, and as m as Dr. Paulsen responded to Erin, Frankel barely notices

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of chromium is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's more than one kind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  There's straight-up chromium -- does all kinds of good things for the body. There's chrom 3, which is fairly benign, and then there's chrom 6, hexavalent chromium, which, depending on the amounts, can be very harmful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harmful, like -- how?  What would you get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With repeated exposure to toxic levels -- God, anything, really -- respiratory disease, liver failure, heart failure, reproductive failure, chronic headaches, bone or organ deterioration -- plus, of course, any type of cancer. He rattles it off coolly.  Just facts.  Erin's stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that stuff -- it kills people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah.  Definitely.  Highly toxic, highly carcinogenic.  Bad, bad stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how do I find out what kind of chromium is up in Hinkley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been to the water board?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunh-uh.  What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every county has one.  They keep records of anything water-related within their jurisdiction.  You should be able to find something there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: County water board.  All righty, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- I wouldn't advertise what you're looking for if I were you ... His line continues over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin's Hyundai pulls up and stops in a cloud of dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Incriminating records have a way of disappearing when people smell trouble. Erin hops out, checks her reflection in the side-view mir then heads into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drab, government-issue.  ROSS, the bored desk clerk is thumbing his way through ROAD & TRACK.  Just as he st stare at a motor oil ad in which a buxom blonde is stradd the hood of a car, the huge door opens and Erin enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whew!  Goddamn, that's a heavy door. Ross looks up.  It's like the girl from the ad walked rig off the page.  He jumps up, to help her with the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hey -- lemme give you a hand there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much.  Aren't you a gentleman?  Mr. ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ross.  Real pleased to meet you.  I'm Erin. She smiles.  He can't believe his luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin.  Cool.  What can I do for you, Erin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, believe it or not, I am on the prowl for some water records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come to the right place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing along)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just tell me what you want to look at and I'll be glad to dig 'em out for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I knew.  It's for my boss.  He's fighting his water bill, and he wants me to find all manner of bills from all kinds of places.  The easiest thing would probably be if I just squeezed back there with you and poked around myself.  Would that be okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heck, yeah.  Come on back.  Just gonna need you to sign in here -- He hands her a pen.  He reads over her shoulder as she si her name -- Erin Pattee Brockovich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pattee?  That your middle name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.  Maiden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not anymore. She smiles and winks at him, then goes around the counter with him and looks at the stacks and stacks of files.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  Here goes nothing. She heads down an aisle, reading the spines of the files. They're all town names -- Barstow, Victorville, Oro Grand Helendale -- in no particular order.  Finally, Erin spots that says Hinkley.  She pulls it down.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE FILE
dialogues.text: are pages and pages of Xeroxed memoranda, letters, charts graphs, handwritten notes.  All shoved in willy-nilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is watching a football game on TV.  He's just put dinners on the floor in front of the Matt and Katie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our mom gives us sandwiches on Fridays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure it is.  Here, I'll show you.  He picks up Matt's chicken, tears it in two ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most people think a sandwich's gotta have  bread on the outside.  Not true.  Chicken is a perfectly good outside for a sandwich. ... then places the broccoli neatly between the halves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See?  Katie and Matthew look at it, then up at George, and smil This guy just might be all right, after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gotten dark.  Erin's Hyundai's still there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin is on the floor, her legs stretched out in front of She has a bunch of files open and spread across the floor The one in her hand has caught her attention.

dialogues.speaker: THE PAPER
dialogues.text: It's a memo titled "CLEAN-UP AND ABATEMENT ORDER" from th water board to PG&E.  Erin is concentrating hard on i reading laboriously to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... On December 7, 1987, the discharger notified the regional board and the San Bernardino County Environmental Health  Services of the discovery of 0.58 ppm of hexavalent chromium in an on-site ground water monitoring well ..." (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... hexavalent ...  INT. MASRY & VITITOE, RECEPTION - DAY  CLOSE ON A XEROX OF THE ABATEMENT ORDER.  WIDEN to see it on top of a stack of papers that Erin is carrying as she enters the office.  She has an efficient air about her -- sense of purpose.  INT. MASRY & VITITOE, FILE ROOM - DAY  Erin swoops in, ready to work, only to find her desk clea off.  She turns to Anna, who's already hard at work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my stuff?  Anna looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where've you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck did you do with my stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't use language with me --  But Erin's out the door before Anna can finish her senten INT. MASRY & VITITOE, JANE'S OFFICE - DAY JANE is at her desk.  Erin barrels in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone stole my stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to see you, Erin.  We've missed you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had photos of my kids, plus a mug --  Jane reaches under her desk for a box, looks through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- toothbrush, toothpaste, and a pair of hose.  Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There may be jobs where you can disappear for days at a time, but this isn't one of  them.  Here, if you don't do the work, you don't get to stay.  She hands her the box.  Erin doesn't take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been working.  Shit, that's all I've been doing.  Ask Mr. Masry.  He knows.  INT. MASRY & VITITOE, ED'S OFFICE - DAY  Ed's at his desk, dialing the phone when Erin barrels in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said to fire me? He sets down the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin, you've been gone for a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I left a message.  I've been dealing with  that real estate thing.  I was gonna write  up a whole damn report and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not how we work here.  You don't just leave a message and take off. Jane follows her in, still carrying the box of stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do, check in every two seconds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  It's called accountability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not talking to you, bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, enough --  (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, look, Erin -- this incident aside, I  don't think this is the right place for you. So what I'm gonna do is make a few calls on  your behalf.  Find you something else, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother.  She turns to Jane, takes her box, and heads out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, I'm trying to help here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit.  You're trying to feel less guilty about firing someone with three kids to feed.  Fuck if I'll help you do that.  And she leaves.  INT. MASRY & VITITOE, OUTSIDE ED'S OFFICE - DAY  As Erin heads for the door, pleased glances fly from  secretary to secretary.  Erin reaches the door, but can't open it with the box in her arms.  She turns to the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't suppose any one of you cunts could open the fucking door for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin's Hyundai rumbles to a stop in front of the house. shoves open the creaky, reluctant door, lifts her box of stuff off the seat, and gets out.  As she walks around the car and toward the house, she run into the MAILMAN.  He hands her a packet of mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here ya go, Miz Brockovich.  Erin looks at the top of the stack.  It's the electric bi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin enters, puts down the box and stares at the mail.  Bills, bills, and more bills.  As she throws them on the table, she sees George coming out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fixing a leak under your sink.  She heads into the kitchen, weary and irritated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't ask you to do that.  Damn it,  George, I don't ask you to do things like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin enters, sees all the cleaning stuff from under the s is spread around the kitchen floor.  A tool box lies open

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna clean it up.  Erin gets down on her knees and starts putting things awa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, Erin, I'll do it -- I'm not -- Before he can finish, a huge WATER BUG runs onto Erin's h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh -- Jesus --  She jumps and brushes it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- you had a whole family of those things hanging out back there.  She takes off her shoe and smacks at the bug, missing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it --  The bug skitters away from her, along the floorboard.  Er chases it, smacking at it repeatedly, missing it every ti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it, I'll get it later.  But Erin keeps after it, corralling all her frustrations killing that one bug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here, you little motherfucker -- The bug crawls up onto the table, zipping behind the salt the pepper, the napkin holder.  Erin keeps after it, BANG the table harder and harder with each SMACK of her shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, whoa -- relax --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The salt and pepper skid off the table.  The napkins fly their holder.  Just as Erin's about to nail the bug, it s into a crack in the wall and disappears.  Erin hurls her at the crack.  It SMASHES into the wall.

dialogues.speaker: GOD DAMN IT
dialogues.text: As Erin stands there staring at the wall, her breath star to come heavily -- those deep breaths that precede tears. She slowly slides down into a chair, defeat overcoming he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost a whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... God damn it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks around at her for-shit kitchen and starts to cr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of person lives like this?  Huh? What kind of person lets her kids run around in a house crawling with bugs the size of housecats?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a simple thing.  Everybody gets them. All we gotta do is call an exterminator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't call an exterminator.  I can't afford one.  God, I can't even afford my phone. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  But you been working so hard --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter.  Doesn't make one bit of difference. (then, fragile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, George, how'd this happen to me? How'd I end up so ... so nothing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George picks a napkin up off the floor, hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not nothing, Erin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sure as hell not what I thought I was gonna be.  I was supposed to have one of those great lives, with everything all laid- out and perfect.  I mean, hell -- I was Miss Wichita, for God's sakes.  Did I tell you that?  You live next door to a real live beauty queen. (wipes her nose)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still got the tiara.  I kept it cause I thought it meant something.  I thought it meant I was gonna do something great with my life.  I thought it proved I was gonna grow up to be someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I'm not.  Look at me.  I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're someone to me. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're someone real special to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a step toward her and kneels in front of her, ve close.  He takes her shoe from her hand and puts it back her foot.  Then he takes her hands in his and kisses them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm no good, George.  I make people miserable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he kisses her anyway.  And for the first time in so l she feels like something other than a failure.  He pulls into him, and she lets herself be pulled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin and George are in bed, naked, curled around each oth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man.  Even your earlobes are beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be too nice to me, okay?  It makes me nervous. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, ED'S OFFICE - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed is at his desk.  The PHONE RINGS.  And RINGS.  And RIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenda! (no answer)

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Nothing.  Ed growls in frustration, then gets the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Ed Masry here ... She doesn't work here anymore.  Who's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON THE TABLE, where Beth is bobbing in her baby cha On one side of her is a heap of bills with "PAST DUE" and "PLEASE REMIT" stamped on them.  On the other, the well- thumbed CLASSIFIED SECTION, with circles and X's all over The DOORBELL rings.  Erin swoops in and picks up Beth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, baby.  Maybe that's Ed McMahon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin carries Beth over to the front door, spies through t peephole, and sees Ed standing there.  She opens the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got an interesting call this afternoon. It was from a Dr. Frankel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wanted you to know the legal limit for hexavalent chromium, is .05 parts per million.  And that at the rate you mentioned, .58, it could be responsible for the cancers in that family you asked about. The Irvings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that was nice of him.  Isn't it funny how some people go out of their way to help people and others just give 'em the ax?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm sorry.  You were gone.  I just assumed you were off having fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, why in the hell would you assume that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Maybe cause you look like someone who has a lot of fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, are you ever a shitty judge of people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed takes a beat, copping to the charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's the story on this thing?  This cancer stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna know, you gotta hire me back.  I got a lot of bills to pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glares at her.  Realizes he has no choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin has let Ed in.  They're sitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, PG&E told her about the chromium?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They told her something, but it can't have been too specific, cause I talked to her, and she sure didn't think her water was bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what made you think it was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't take a genius to look at those medical records and think something's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What medical records?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ones in the box of files. (off Ed's blank look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The box of files?  The one from your office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't see any medical records in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, you musta really fine-tooth-combed it then, huh? (to herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you fired me.  Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed thinks for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That document you found, the one that says it was the bad chromium -- you didn't happen to make a copy did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme see it, will you? Before getting it for him, she looks at him, weighs her o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want a raise.  And benefits.  Including dental.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Erin, this is not the way I do business, this extortion nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin doesn't budge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  A 5% raise, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten. (off his look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a lot of other places I could work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ten percent raise and benefits.  But that's it.  I'm drawing the line. She goes to her box of stuff from the office and digs out document for him.  He scans it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the only thing you found?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So far.  But that place is a pig sty.  I wouldn't be surprised if there's more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin's Hyundai zips along the freeway.  "Funky Town" is blaring from the tinny stereo.  Over it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate this music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin's driving.  Matthew's in the front seat.  Katie and (in a car seat) are in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no way a son of mine hates Funky Town.  It's impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I hate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate it too.  I hate this trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, where's your sense of adventure?  We're going someplace you never been before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna hate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too. She glances at them, frowns a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I'm realizing for the first time?  You kids are a couple of downers.  I mean, you are the real thing -- a couple of honest-to-God depresso-types. (small smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who in the heck raised you, anyway?  Some kind of moron?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie smiles a little.  She likes this side of her mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  A real moron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some kind of half-wit, no-good, big-haired, bimbo, I bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (also smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God we got you away from her, huh? By now they're all smiling.  Funky Town plays on. EXT. PG&E COMPRESSOR STATION - DAY The Hyundai is parked at the entrance to the station, by row of dead trees.  Erin is standing beside a sign that s "Private Property.  No Trespassing", taking pictures of t massive structure in the distance.  Matthew, Katie, and B are drawing in the dirt with sticks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay out of the road.  I'll be right back. She wanders up the drive, onto PG&E property, moving the plant, taking pictures of it from every possible angl As she wanders over a big, flat, dry field to the side of plant, she glances over her shoulder to check on her kids notices the trail she made in the dirt has a greenish hue She looks at the dirt right her feet.  Kicks the ground. Below the surface, the dirt turns from brown to green.  E notes this, then looks back at her kids playing in the di Worry comes over her face.  She heads back to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids are waiting at the car.  Erin comes out of the s with a bottle of water and uses it to rinse off their han

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of a BABY CRYING.  The Hyundai's parked in fron

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin is at the Xerox machine, copying a file while she tr to calm Beth.  There's a stack of files on the nearby tab Matthew and Katie are flopping around on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll go eat in a minute.  Settle down. Whining, fussing.  Ross goes over to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what, Erin?  I got nothing but time here.  Why don't you let me do that for you, and you can get your kids some dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ross -- you are an absolute angel. She hands Ross the STACK OF DOCUMENTS. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, BRENDA'S DESK - DAY Ed comes in in the morning, and without pausing, hands Br a copy of the STACK OF DOCUMENTS, with a Post-it on the t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fax these to this number, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of them. He continues into his office and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: THE FAX MACHINE LED
dialogues.text: Brenda types in the number.  The recipient's I.D. comes u the LED: PG&E CLAIMS DEPT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another copy of those DOCUMENTS, now in Donna's hands.  S on her couch with Erin, reading them.  Outside, Donna's t daughters are playing in the pool.  She reads the last pa and looks up at Erin, bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An on-site monitoring well?  That means --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was right up on the PG&E property over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you say this stuff, this hexavalent chromium -- it's poisonous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- then it's gotta be a different than what's in our water, cause ours is okay. The guys from PG&E told me.  They sat right in the kitchen and said it was fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  But the toxicologist I been talking to?  He gave me a list of problems that can come from hexavalent chromium exposure. And everything you all have is on that list. Donna resists this idea hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Hunh-uh, see, that's not what the doctor said.  He said one's got absolutely nothing to do with the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, but -- didn't you say he was paid by PG&E? Donna sits quietly, trying to make sense of this.  The on sound is the LAUGHING and SPLASHING from the pool out bac Then, gradually, Donna realizes what it is she's hearing her kids playing in toxic water.  She jumps up ...

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: ... and runs out to the pool.  Erin follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the door, Erin watches Donna run to the edge of the in a frantic response to this news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: Erin watches compassionately as Donna flails to get her k out of the contaminated water. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, ED'S OFFICE - DAY It's morning.  Ed is checking the lie of his tie in his reflection in the window.  Erin is on his couch, high-hee legs stretched out in front of her. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, BRENDA'S DESK - CONTINUOUS Jane is delivering paychecks.  When Brenda gets to her de Jane tips her head toward Ed's office, as if to say, chec out.  Brenda peers in and sees Erin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's she doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hired her back.  With a raise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What??  Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's see.  It's not cause she's smart, and it's not cause she's professional.  That leaves ... Brenda's stunned.  Takes a beat.  Makes assumptions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
