dialogues.text: And dumb old me thought working hard and being loyal was the way to get ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed is still checking his reflection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, the minute Brenda sent the fax -- I'm talking the second she pressed that send button -- PG&E claims department is on the phone to me, scheduling a meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you think we got 'em scared?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sure as hell sounded like they were sitting up and taking notice. Brenda pops her head in, ignores Erin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Baum from PG&E is at reception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin feels the chill Brenda's sending her way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to see you again, too, Brenda. Brenda leaves without acknowledging Erin. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, MAIN ROOM - DAY Ed and Erin come out and see DAVID BAUM waiting at recept Forget law school, this kid looks like he's just out of twelfth grade.  Not a hair on his chin.  His suit and sho look brand new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to question your judgment or anything, Mr. Masry, but -- that doesn't exactly look like sitting up and taking notice to me. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, CONFERENCE ROOM - DAY Ed and Erin are seated across the table from Baum. To say this kid lacks authority is a gross understatement.  He doesn't talk; he squeaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... in the interest of putting this whole thing to rest, PG&E is willing to offer the Irvings 250,000 dollars for their home. Ed laughs a little in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In terms of land value out in Hinkley, Mr. Masry, we feel it's a more than fair price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about in terms of medical expenses? 250,000 doesn't come close to what this family's gonna have to spend on doctors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand they've had a bad run of luck, health-wise, and they have my sympathies. But that's not PG&E's fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding, right? (Baum doesn't answer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at these readings for Christ's sake. PG&E's own technicians documented toxic levels of hexavalent chromium in those test wells, on numerous occasions. Ed shoves them across the table.  Baum doesn't look at th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything the Irvings have had is a proven reaction to exposure to hexavalent chromium. They've had ... He stalls a moment.  Erin jumps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- breast cysts, uterine cancer, Hodgkin's disease, immune deficiencies, asthma, chronic nosebleeds. Despite their persuasiveness, Baum parrots what is obviou the party line:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A million things could have caused those problems.  Poor diet, bad genes, irresponsible lifestyle.  Our offer is final and more than fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute -- I thought we were negotiating here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 250,000 is all I'm authorized to offer. Ed looks across at this pissant little kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. (he stands, to leave)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will present your offer to my clients.  I doubt they'll accept it. As Ed starts out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Masry, before you go off on some crusade, you might want to remember who it is you're dealing with here.  PG&E is a 28- billion dollar corporation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (containing his anger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.  I'll keep it in mind. And Ed leaves the conference room.  Erin follows him out. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, MAIN ROOM - DAY Erin follows Ed as he stomps back to his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least they made an offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't an offer.  A million would've been an offer.  When they send the God damn mail clerk down to jerk me off, waste my time, it's a fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get why they'd do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because they can.  You heard that kid -- they have 28 billion dollars at their disposal.  They can afford to waste all the time in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you can't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, you think I'm made of money? Behind them, Baum steps out of the conference room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you know where I can get a cab?  My plane leaves Burbank in forty-five minutes. Ed turns and looks at him.  He gets a tiny smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you what, why don't you go on over to reception, tell them I said Mario should take you to the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, excellent.  Thanks. Baum heads out to the reception area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Masry, Mario gets lost going to the bathroom.  They'll be driving around the valley for hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gleeful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Isn't that a shame? She watches him go into his office, impressed.  Big smile

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'll be God damned. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, OUTSIDE ED'S OFFICE - NIGHT End of the day.  Most everyone has left.  Erin is at her work space near Ed's office.  She's poring over a fat fil documents.  ROSALIND wanders by with her coat on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been reading for hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a slow reader, on account of the fact that I look at the word "dog" and see "god".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, just so long as you see Him. Rosalind turns on Erin's desk lamp and heads out. Outside the big glass office doors, Rosalind stops to tal a lost-looking COUPLE IN THEIR MID-30's.  These are MANDY TOM BROWN.  He's a security guard uniform, with an envelo under his arm.  Rosalind points to Erin.  The Browns ente the office and approach her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, are you Erin Brockovich?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Tom Brown.  This is my wife Mandy.  We used to live across the street from the Irvings.  PG&E bought our house last year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON photos of chickens, each with a twisted, limp ne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called wry neck.  It's when they're born without any muscles in the neck. WIDEN to see Erin looking at them with Tom and Mandy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.  How many were born like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve, maybe thirteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Donna told us about you, and what you told her about the chromium, we figured that might have something to do with this, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sure could, yeah.  Thanks a lot. She tucks them into a file, as if that's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something else, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  Mandy here's had nine miscarriages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding?  My God --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  It's an awful lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm surprised Donna didn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't know.  No one does.  It's not something you want to talk about, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured it musta been something I did, like when I smoked marijuana, maybe.  Or took birth control pills.  But then Donna told me you thought this chromium might be to blame for her problems, so I figured ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt and Katie are in bed, with the light off.  Erin come in, quietly, in clothes from work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.  You guys still awake? CLOSE ON MATT AND KATIE.  They're awake and pissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, now.  No faking.  George told me he just shut out the light a few seconds ago. They still don't answer.  She comes in and sits on a bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I know you're mad.  But the way this job is, things come up at the last minute, real important things, and I gotta deal with them.  Now I don't like me missing dinner any more than you do, but we're all gonna have to get used to it, cause the fact is, it's gonna happen sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It happens all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true; we had dinner together just last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were reading the whole time. He's got a point there.  Erin feels like shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, pumpkins.  I'll try a whole lot harder to be around, okay?  I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is dark.  Erin enters and flops down onto the be exhausted.  George is lying on the bed next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's any consolation, I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dry, flat California.  Ed's big old Mercedes is toodling the freeway, at an overly safe, almost-geriatric speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank Sinatra is playing on the stereo.  Ed is swaying in time.  This is his kind of music.  He smiles, looks at Er

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Sinatra's world, we just live in it. Whatever.  Erin glances at the speedometer.  Oy.  So slow His car phone rings.  He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? ... (his voice softens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, babys.  Baby's fine.  Yes, I did.  I did, too, you just didn't feel it. He starts swerving across the lane markers.  THWACK THWAC THWACK.  Ed doesn't notice.  Erin's getting nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I could leave without kissing my babys?  Okay, here you go. He kisses into the phone.  Swerves.  A car barely misses them.  Erin's eyes widen.  Not fun at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye-bye ... bye-bye ... no, you.  Okay, together.  Bye-bye. He finally hangs up, smiling to himself.  Erin clears her throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um -- you mind pulling over?  Just -- for a second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mercedes pulls to a stop on the shoulder.  Erin gets walks around to the driver's side.  Opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of all, don't talk baby talk to your wife in front of me.  It really undermines your authority.  And second, I know you're my boss and all, but you are the worst fucking driver I've ever seen.  Move over or I quit. He moves over.  She gets in, turns off the Sinatra.  They pull back out onto the freeway in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mercedes and a truck are parked out front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something about this whole thing I don't quite understand, Mr. Masry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna and Pete Irving, and Mandy and Roy Brown are all seated, sipping iced tea.  While they talk, Erin hands th all information packets on chromium.  Ed is standing in f of them, a little stiff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If PG&E messed with our water, why would they bother saying anything about it to us? Why not just keep quiet about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To establish a statute of limitations.  See, in a case like this, you only have a year from the time you first learn about the problem to file suit.  So PG&E figures, we'll let the cat out of the bag -- tell the people the water's not perfect; if we can ride out the year with no one suing, we'll be in the clear forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it was more than a year ago that they told us --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.  We're not suing.  All we're doing is using this information to get you a real nice purchase price on your house, and get you two -- (to the Browns)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- a comparable retroactive bonus added to your sale price.  This way, and PG&E can still look good to their shareholders, cause they're not involved in an ugly lawsuit; all they're doing is buying a little property. Roy looks up from his retainer agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't say here how much this whole thing's gonna cost us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My fee's forty percent of whatever you get awarded. Erin watches them look around at each other, stunned by t figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, do I know how you feel.  First time I heard that number, I said you got to be kidding me.  Forty God damn percent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the one who's injured, and this joker who sits at a desk all day is gonna walk away with almost half my reward?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin -- Erin's enjoying Ed's discomfort almost too much to stop. just almost.  She shifts gears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I asked him how much he makes if I didn't get anything. They look at Ed.  Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I don't get anything either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I realized, he's taking a chance too. When they hear this, and realize he's in it with them, th all reach for their pens and sign.   They hand the agreem over to Erin, who takes them across the room to Ed.  He stuffs them in his briefcase and closes it up.  That's th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then.  Let's hit the road. Boy.  Cold as ice.  Erin stares at him, stunned by his brusque manner, then leans in to him, close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Masry, if you don't mind my saying, you got a lot to learn about being friendly. These people just hired you as their lawyer. The least you could do is make a little pleasant conversation. She gives him a stern look, then turns toward the women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna, let me help you clean all this up. She picks up a tray of iced tea and cookies and heads to kitchen.  Donna and Mandy follow, leaving Ed alone with P and Roy.  He stands there, awkwardly.  Then, finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what's, uh ... what's new?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin and Donna are putting away the cleaned glasses.  Man is scanning the chromium pamphlet Erin gave her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that thing it says in here about rashes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this old neighbor of mine, Bob Linwood -- he ran the dairy on Community -- seemed like someone in his family always had a rash somewhere or other.  I just figured it was something in the genes.  And you know how it is -- you don't like to ask about things like that ... Erin listens, interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another day.  BOB LINWOOD, 40's and gruff, is in the barn tossing hay around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.  Are you Mr. Linwood? He sees Erin picking her way toward him in her high-heels

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Erin Brockovich.  I work at the law firm that represents your former neighbors the Browns.  They suggested I give you a call. She steps in a cow patty.  Laughs at herself good-natured

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy howdy, did I ever wear the wrong shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON A SIGN that reads: THE DESOTOS, hanging on the s of a small, paint-chipped house.  Erin is at the door tal to MARY DESOTO, 65, who's wearing a big cross at her brea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and Mr. Linwood seemed to think that your husband had been sick as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. DeSoto has lung cancer.  Never smoked a day in his life, neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin is talking to MIKE and LAURA AMBROSINO -- 30's.  Sol family folks.  But Laura's left brow and cheekbone look swollen and misshapen, and she's trying to hide the fact she's in a lot of pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. DeSoto said she wasn't sure exactly what it was that you had --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not alone on that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they know what it is -- it's called fibrous dysplasia --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bones start growing again.  Gives her headaches like you wouldn't believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- they just don't know what caused it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin is talking to TED AND RITA DANIELS.  Their daughter ANNABELLE, 10, is sitting on the couch, wrapped in a blan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... then Mike Ambrosino remembered seeing you folks at the hospital from time to time too, so I thought I'd just stop by. (to Annabelle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be Annabelle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whew, are you ever a beauty.  I mean, you must drive those boys crazy. Annabelle smiles a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late night.  George rolls over -- Erin's side of the bed empty.  He checks the clock, then gets up and heads into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He peers around and spots her, sitting in the little kid' chair in Matthew and Katie's room. Erin is holding Beth, watching Matt and Katie sleep.  Eri hears the floor creak as George steps into the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something, George.  What kind of God lets a beautiful little 10-year-old girl get brain cancer?  Isn't He supposed to be in charge of stuff like that?  Make sure it doesn't happen? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear, any other job, He'd be fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed and Erin are walking down the street, take-out coffee in their hands.  Ed is sipping his, but Erin is in too mu of a lather to drink hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunh-uh.  Absolutely not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's crazy -- why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I said no.  Look -- the only reason PG&E's even talking to us is cause this is a quiet little real estate dispute.  We add plaintiffs, and suddenly we're in the middle of a toxic tort -- with a statute problem -- against a massive utility.  No, thank you. They go into their office building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin and Ed are riding up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, so here's what I'll do.  I'll go on up to Ted and Rita Daniels -- two of the nicest people you'd ever hope to meet, who spend every single day watching their little girl fight like a dog against this cancer -- I'll tell them we can't help them cause you don't feel like working that hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not about working hard --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- It's about being realistic.  Something like this, Erin -- it could take forever. They're a huge corporation.  They'd completely bury us in paperwork.  I'm just one guy with a shitty little P.I. firm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- who happens to know they poisoned people and lied about it. The doors open.  Ed gets off.  Erin follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin's dogging Ed down the hall, to the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this shit is bad news, Mr. Masry.  Not only does it attack every organ of the body, it fucks with your DNA, too.  That means these people's genes, and the genes of their kids, and the genes of their grandkids --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how DNA works, Erin -- He gets to the Masry & Vititoe doors.  Opens them. INT. MASRY & VITITOE - DAY Erin tails Ed back to his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can get these people.  With a little effort, I really think we can nail their asses to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you do?  With all your legal expertise, you believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, fine.  I don't know shit about shit. But I know the difference -- He shuts his office door on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed goes over to his desk, sits down.  He sees a stack of messages there, starts flipping through them.  Then he st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it. He shoves the messages aside and puts his head in his han He sits like that for a moment, GROANS to himself.  Then pushes himself up and heads over to his door. When he opens it, he finds Erin still standing there, exa where he left her, arms crossed.  She hasn't budged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many families we talking about here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four more.  Eleven people.  So far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think there's more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- I found one document at the water board that had a toxic test well reading from 1967.  A hell of a lot of people have lived on that land since then. Ed pauses, groans again, realizing what decision he's mak

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a whole different ball game, Erin. A much bigger deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kinda like David and what's-his-name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kinda like David and what's-his-name's whole fucking family. (heavy sigh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, here's the deal -- if, and only if, you find me the evidence to back all this up -- I'll do it.  I'll take it on. She smiles victoriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing the right thing, Mr. Masry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah.  Remind me of that when I'm filing for bankruptcy. He heads back to his desk.  Erin follows him into his off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course, gathering evidence -- now, that's a big job.  A hell of a lot bigger than just filing.  I'm gonna be working a lot harder now, taking on a lot more responsibility ... He gives her a look.  Knows what's coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another raise wouldn't hurt.  And with all the time I'm gonna be spending on the road, I'll probably be needing my own cel phone, won't I?

dialogues.speaker: A BEEPING CEL PHONE
dialogues.text: as Erin tries to program numbers into its speed dial.  WI to see she is reading from the phone's manual as she ente Toys 'R' Us with George, Matthew, Katie and Beth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You each can pick out four things.  But nothing huge.  Look at the price.  Nothing crazy. Matthew and Katie fan out into the store.  Erin keeps mes with the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can buy 'em all the toys you want, but come Monday, when you split again, they're still gonna be pissed. Erin looks over at him, weary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, I am just trying to do something nice for my kids on my one day off.  Could you please not give me a hard time about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One toy per kid is doing something nice. Four is ... something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hell, I guess that's it, then, huh? They're scarred for life.  They're gonna start holding up 7-11's any day now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with intensity)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you're saying, and I don't wanna hear it.  I am doing the best I can. And she walks away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin, in high heels and miniskirt, is straddling a ditch, scooping clumps of gunky moss from the ditch into plastic containers.  Over this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Frankel, it's Erin Brockovich.  Tell me something: if I wanna find as much evidence of hexavalent chromium contamination as I possibly can, what should I do? As Erin labels the containers, her heels slide down the s of the ditch, and she lands smack in it, knee-deep in gun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin, now completely dirty, is climbing over a fence mark "No Trespassing".  Her arms are full of more containers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what you have to remember is, if you have hex chrom in the water, you have it in anything that lived off the water. She adds them to a growing collection of containers in th trunk of her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another day.  This time it's RAINING.  Erin minces her wa down to the deep end of the pool in her spike heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I'd do is start a collection.  Anything that existed in water, on water, under water ... She gets to the deep end and scoops up a Ziploc full of rancid pool water and seals it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: anything that had water flow over or under it ... Erin spots a few dead frogs in the water.  She picks one by the leg, and seals it in a plastic bag as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a sample cup held in her teeth, Erin hauls herself u over the well's concrete wall, then, with her back agains one side of the well and her feet against the other, star shimmying down the well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: anything that had water pass through it ...

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE WELL
dialogues.text: she winces at the algae and gook that's clinging to her a she descends to the water level.  When she's low enough, takes the sample cup from her teeth and scoops up the wat INT. MASRY & VITITOE, ERIN'S DESK - DAY Erin's at her desk, bending over her notebook in a minisk adding reports to the TOXICOLOGY binder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... collect 'em, label 'em, then bring 'em to me.  I'll analyze 'em, see what we got. ON THE REPORTS: We catch a few words: "water sample A ... "soil sample D ...", "frog sample A ...", "... traces of hexavalent ..." Brenda looks at Erin and sees her hem rising in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake, Erin, I can see your panties. Erin turns to Brenda, relishing the chance to irritate he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liar.  I'm not wearing any. Ed, in his office, laughs.  He's starting to like this ga

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a hot night.  George is playing on the floor with th kids.  Erin is behind them on the couch, laboriously read a book labeled, simply, CHROMIUM.  The phone RINGS.  Erin picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this the Erin Pattee Brockovich that's been snooping around the water board? His voice is flat, creepy.  Not friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Who's this? CLICK.  Erin stares at the phone, freaked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George watches Erin double-checking the locks on the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna quit cause of one creepy phone call, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Erin.  A job's supposed to pay your bills, not put you in danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not in danger.  I have a dead bolt. Remember? She goes to the living room, double-checks the window loc in there.  George follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, don't take this the wrong way, but don't you think you might be out of your league here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, see -- that's exactly what those arrogant PG&E fucks want me to think -- that because they got all this money and power, we don't stand a chance in hell against them.  But you know what?  They're wrong. She heads into the bedrooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't have to be this complicated, Erin.  There's a lot of jobs out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you know? George reacts, a little stung.  He follows her into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt and Katie are asleep.  Erin is checking their window George comes in.  They whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mind telling me what that's supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you got a problem with me taking care of your kids instead of getting some job, just say so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause I can get a job.  I will.  And you can start leaving the kids with the chicken fat lady again.  Would that make you happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your voice down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what they can sleep through, Erin.  I probably know it better than you. She gives him a glare, then leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin is reaching up to a high shelf for a dusty old box o files.  Out of the corner of her eye, she sees Ross passi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ross.  Tell me something.  Does PG&E pay you to cover their ass, or do you just do it out of the kindness of your heart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bad liar)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fuck you don't.  No one calls me Pattee. That heavy-breathing sicko that called the other night could've only found out about me from you. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are dying, Ross.  You got document after document here, right under your nose, that says why, and you haven't said word one about it.  I wanna know how the hell you sleep at night. Ross is speechless.  He just stands there.  Erin drags th box to the floor and goes to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin's car is parked in front.  A DIRTY OLD PICK-UP comes rumbling up the road.  When its lights hit Erin's car, it slows, then pulls over.  The driver flicks on his BRIGHTS get a better look at the car.  The truck sits there for a bit, a dark presence.  Then, as the headlights of another appear down the road, the truck goes back in gear, pulls and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pile of documents is strapped into the passenger seat. empty coffee cup rolls around the floor.  Erin's driving, exhausted.  She yawns as she dials her phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? INTERCUT between Erin in her car, and George in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so tired I'm about to drive off the road.  Keep me awake, willya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want, a joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no jokes, I gotta pee.  Just tell me about your day.  What went on back there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, come to think of it, we did have a big event around here.  Beth started talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth?  My Beth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  We were sitting around at lunch and she pointed at a ball and said, "ball." Erin says nothing, just stares out at the empty highway, feeling all hollowed-out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd never seen that before -- someone's first word.  Pretty intense. Erin just nods.  Keeps staring straight ahead as a tear r down her cheek. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, ERIN AND BRENDA'S AREA - DAY CLOSE ON SOME FILES as Erin hands them to Ed.  As he take them from her, he notices a crematory urn on Erin's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what I think it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lived on the plume.  You never know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed laughs and hands the documents to Brenda without looki at her.  She grumpily takes them over to the fax machine. CLOSE ON THE FAX LED as Brenda types in the number. The recipient's name comes up again: PG&E CLAIMS DEPT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open pits, pony rides, watermelon.  George is watching Ka and Matt being led around on ponies, an activity that sto being fun hours ago.  Now they're just hot and tired. BY THE BARBECUE, Ed is talking to an OLDER COUPLE as they sign retainer agreements. ELSEWHERE, Erin, holding Beth, is looking at pictures of swimming pool with FIVE OTHER WOMEN.  The water is green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was the community pool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that PG&E built.  The whole time we thought it was algae that made it so green. LATER ... Erin's trunk is open.  She and Ed are clipping new cluste of retainer agreements into the "PLAINTIFFS" binder. LATER STILL ... Erin and Ed are passing out informational pamphlets.  She sticks one in a hand before noticing that it's George's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm bored, and so are the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a few more minutes, then we can go. (as he heads off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take her, will you? George drops the pamphlet and takes Beth from Erin.  He h over to Matt and Katie, sitting glumly on a log. As he steps away, a hand reaches down and grabs the flier dropped.  It belongs to a MAN IN A BLACK JACKET.  He's in 50's, strong and sinewy.  Military-style dark glasses obs his eyes.  He scans the pamphlet, then watches Erin worki the crowd.  Watches her carefully.  He slides the pamphle into his inside pocket, and heads back his car -- the DIR OLD PICK-UP TRUCK that idled in front of the Water Board. LATER STILL ... Erin is heading over to George and the kids, ready to lea when Donna comes up to her, with A MIDDLE-AGED MAN in tow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin, this here's Frank Melendez.  He works over at the compressor station -- Erin stops in her tracks, very interested. LATER STILL ... Erin and Frank are on a bench, talking.  Out of the corne her eye, she sees her car drive off.  George's hand stick out the driver's side and flips her the bird.  She watche him disappear, then, hiding her rage, turns back to Frank

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  What were you saying? LATER ... The barbecue is winding down.  Ed is heading for his Mercedes.  Erin storms up beside him, mad as all get-out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed is driving.  He glances over at Erin, fuming in the passenger seat.  After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna talk about --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Another beat.  Then Erin's cel phone rings.  She digs int her bag, pulling it out as fast as she can.  Answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, asshole? There's a pause.  Then Mike Ambrosino's voice comes over line, very strained:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, Erin?  This is Mike.  Ambrosino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The curtains are drawn; everything is dark.  Ed and Erin at the door, talking to Mike, who looks drawn and tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was about to take a handful of these -- He shows them a bottle of prescription pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a morphine thing -- for pain -- Erin nods, then leaves Ed with Mike and heads toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin opens the door.  Very dark, very quiet.  Laura is ly in bed.  Erin goes over to her.  They speak in whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay.  I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just -- the pain.  It's only getting worse.  I can't be a good wife.  I can't be a good mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm real sorry, Laura. Erin sits down on the chair next to the bed.  Takes a bea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what I always thought I wanted outta life, Erin?  A Jaguar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaguar's a darn pretty car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought if I could spend that kinda money on a car, it'd mean everything else was fine. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even know how much they cost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot.  But you hang in there, maybe you'll get one. Laura shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't mean the same thing. Erin watches her sadly. INT. PG&E COMPRESSOR STATION - DAY A LOUD, industrial plant.  Erin and Frank Melendez walk through, him in coveralls, her in a teensy sun dress.  Bo in hard-hats.  He's giving her a tour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, in his leather and denim, is walking down the sidewalk.  As we WIDEN, we see he's pushing a PINK STROLL He stops at a crosswalk, waiting for the light to change. In the stroller, Beth starts to whine.  George reaches in pocket, finds her pacifier.  As he's leaning down to give to her, he hears a RUMBLE coming down the street behind h The roar grows.  He stands, looks.  A GROUP OF ABOUT TEN BIKERS has pulled up next to him.  He looks at them.  The look at him, then at the stroller.  George feels ridiculo When the light changes, the bikers REV LOUDLY and pull ou George just stands there and watches them go. INT. MASRY & VITITOE - NIGHT His office is all about Hinkley.  A map of the plume area a diagram of the plant cover one wall; photos of the plan cover the credenza; piles of documents litter every surfa Erin is up at the map, eating Chinese food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They used the hex chrom here, in these cooling tanks, as an anti-corrosive.  Then they dumped it here, in these six ponds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember seeing any ponds up there. She bites into a forkful of food, keeps talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They covered 'em over.  And not too carefully either, cause you dig one inch under the surface, and the dirt is green as a fucking shamrock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's what caused the contamination?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It didn't help, but no.  The real problem's on the bottom. She reaches for a document, reads from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, according to this, they were supposed to line the ponds so this shit couldn't seep into the ground.  But guess what --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They skipped that step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it was a little too inconvenient. So for fourteen years, this stuff flowed into the groundwater, free as you please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even wanna ask what you did to make this Melendez guy talk. In response to the insinuation, Erin gives him a glare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For your information, Frank cares what was in those ponds 'cause he used to spend half his day wading around them.  That was his job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- Suddenly, her eyes pop out of her head --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHIT!  SHIT!  Hot!  Hot!  Hot! Tears spring to her eyes.  She fans furiously at her mout Ed finds the tequila from the client and hands it to her. She takes a swig.  There's a nanosecond of relief ... unt the tequila hits.  Her eyes redden.  She spews and gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ... asshole ... Ed chuckles. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, ED'S OFFICE - LATER The tequila's been dipped into.  Ed and Erin are each lyi on a couch, staring at documents.  Late-night working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin -- lemme tell you something.  If I'da put three researchers on this, I wouldn't expect them to dig up all the information you got here.  This is some damn good work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  Then gimme another raise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I got a staff to pay, plus rent, plus I haven't billed a minute of my time since I started on this case, so you can quit hitting me up like I'm rich or something. He gets up, grabs his trash can, and moves around the roo with it, cleaning up all the Chinese food cartons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give me that.  You're gonna get plenty rich off of this, Mr. 40 percent.  We got those PG&E fuckers by the balls here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got the PG&E fuckers in Hinkley by the balls.  But nobody's getting rich unless we can pin this on the corporate PG&E fuckers in San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PG&E corporate is claiming they had no way of knowing what was going on in Hinkley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they knew.  They had to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me the document that proves that. She doesn't have one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then they didn't know.  And if they didn't know, we can't hit 'em for punitive damages. And punitive damages is where the money is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Ed -- you know, the more I work on this thing, the more I realize what a crock of shit this legal system is.  Here we got a company that poisoned a whole aquifer -- that built a pool for a town, then filled it with toxic water -- and we're the ones who've gotta bust our ass proving things?  That's just not right. Beat.  Ed smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like this case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  It makes me sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too.  That's why I like it.  It's been a long time since I had a case I cared about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't care about my case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would now. He gives her a long look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.  I like working with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, good, Ed.  I like working with you too. They both smile a little awkwardly.  Take a beat.  Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When'd you start calling me Ed? INT. MASRY & VITITOE - NIGHT The Christmas party.  The office is decorated; someone is Santa.  Erin and George enter, all dressed up. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, HALLWAY - NIGHT Erin's giving George a guided tour.  As they head down th hall, every desk is decorated and has a present on it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying -- we have one night to ourselves, why do we have to spend it here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause it's my office party.  If you had an office, I'd go to your party. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, ERIN AND BRENDA'S DESKS - NIGHT It's dark.  The door to Erin's area opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here, ta-daa, is my desk. She flicks on the lights.  Brenda's desk is decorated and a present on it.  Erin's is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one? (it's obvious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe they didn't think you were coming. Erin shakes her head.  She's surprised by how hurt she is

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn.  I work so hard.  The least they could do ... George looks over at her, sees her eyes glisten a little. goes over to her, wraps his arms around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.  Fuck 'em, babe.  Who needs 'em, huh? He kisses her.  She leans into him.  He kisses her some m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See?  All we need is each other. She kisses back.  She's gonna let him take care of her. more kisses, heating up.  He slides her onto her empty de

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good thing there isn't a present there, huh? That mighta hurt. She laughs a little.  He slides his hands up her skirt. pulls him into her, tugging his shirt out of his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed is coming down the hall with his wife, JOEY.  Joey is younger than Ed, and very pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll show you what we did back here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin and George, in a rapidly-heating-up clinch on her de hear the voices.  Erin pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lock the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I wanna say hi. He pulls her back into him, not wanting to move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll say hi later.  Lock it. But Erin pulls away ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, George, it's a party. He watches her straighten her dress and take a step away him.  It's just one step, but it feels a hell a lot farth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin and Ed are at the reception desk, talking and laughi NEARBY, Joey and George are standing together, awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your wife's real pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matthew lies awake in his bed, listening to George and Er fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wouldn't kill you to talk about something other than yourself and your own fucking job once in a while --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to talk about instead? Your day?  That's a fascinating subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin and George are fighting while they get ready for bed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.  Just cause I don't spend all day trying to prove what hot shit I am --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is not what I'm --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit, Erin.  Bullshit. The fight is interrupted by the sound of BETH CRYING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.  Excellent.  Thank you very much. She leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth is wailing in her crib.  Erin comes in in her nights and lifts Beth out.  Then, more to herself than to Beth:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, baby.  It'll be okay. She runs her hand over Beth's head, then slides down the and crumples onto the floor.  As she curls around Beth, E starts to COUGH.  Deep, raspy coughs from way down low. EXT. PG&E STATION - NIGHT Late, late at night.  The plant is silent.  The property seems empty, until we notice Pete Irving standing alone inside the gates, staring up at the station. After a beat, he picks up a rock and hurls it at the plan It misses.  Not that it would do anything if it hit.  He reaches for another, throws it.  Then another, and anothe He hurls rock after rock at the gigantic plant.  Then, overwhelmed by his impotence, he lets out a TERRIFYING YE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna's sitting quietly in bed.  Erin is sitting on the e of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd got so used to having 'em come up benign, I guess I just didn't expect it. She looks down her shirt front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure wish I had longer to get used to the idea. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think if you got no uterus, and no breasts, you're still technically a woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you are.  You're just a happier woman, cause you don't have to deal with maxi-pads and underwire. Donna smiles a little.  Then her face crumbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna get them, aren't we, Erin?  You gotta promise me we're gonna get them. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, DAY

dialogues.speaker: THE FAX LED
dialogues.text: as DOCUMENTS are faxed once again to the PG&E CLAIMS THEN AGAIN, on another day. AND AGAIN, on another day. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, ED'S OFFICE - DAY Ed is once again checking the lie of his tie in a window. Erin is popping some aspirin, trying to kill a headache t has brought with it a healthy dose of intolerance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they've sent that little shmuck Baum again, I'm gonna be real pissed off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From their tone of voice on the phone, I'd say they're taking us more seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I heard that one before. Brenda leans her head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Sanchez, Mr. Webster, Mr. Buda, and Ms. Cooper, from PG&E are here. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, RECEPTION AREA - DAY Talk about moving up the food chain.  MS. SANCHEZ, MR. WEBSTER, MR. BUDA, and MR. COOPER mill slowly about the reception area like sharks.  They all ooze importance. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, OUTSIDE OF ED'S OFFICE - DAY Erin, Ed and Brenda are staring out at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.  They look like the Secret Service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're trying to intimidate us. (then, to Brenda)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell them to wait in the conference room. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, CONFERENCE ROOM - DAY Sanchez, Webster, Buda, and Cooper are seated. The door opens and Ed enters, legal pad under his arm. Followed by Erin, legal pad under her arm.  Followed by A (looking professional in Brenda's suit coat), legal pad u her arm.  Followed by Mario (in a suit produced from who knows where), legal pad under his arm.  If you didn't kno better, you'd assume it was a team of lawyers as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Counselors --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Counselors. Ed and Erin sit down and get to work.  Mario and Anna, clearly told to just follow along, sit down a moment late INT. MASRY & VITITOE, CONFERENCE ROOM - LATER Mario and Anna are sitting mutely in their seats beside E and Erin, firing blank looks across the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's be honest, here.  Two million dollars is more money than these people have ever dreamed of. Erin has no patience for this today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, see, now that pisses me off.  First of all -- we got more'n a hundred plaintiffs. They may not be sophisticated, but they do know how to divide, and two million dollars isn't shit when it's split between them. Mario and Anna exchange a look.  This is getting interest

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin -- But there's no stopping her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And second of all -- these people don't dream about being rich.  They dream about being able to watch their kids swim in a pool without worrying they'll have to have a hysterectomy at age 20, like Rosa Diaz -- a client of ours -- or have their spine deteriorate like Stan Bloom.  Another client of ours.  So before you come back here with another lame-ass offer, I want you to think real hard about what your spine is worth, Mr. Buda -- or what you'd expect someone to pay you for your uterus, Miss Sanchez -- then you take out your calculator and multiply that number by a hundred.  Anything less than that is a waste of our time. And she gets up and storms out of the meeting. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, COFFEE AREA - DAY Erin drinks a big swig of coffee and pops a few more aspi Beyond her, the PG&E lawyers are filing out of the of Anna wanders over to Erin, a little uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, Erin? (Erin turns)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen.  Even though you're not necessarily my favorite person in the world ... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... sometimes you're not half-bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna assume that was meant as a compliment, Anna, and just say thank you. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, ERIN'S DESK - NIGHT Erin's at her desk, which is completely buried in documen and files.  She's visibly exhausted, struggling to focus the page, and COUGHING while she works.  Ed calls to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.  A new plaintiff called, wants to meet you.  I told him we'd be out there Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'you get his name? (no answer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course not.  Jesus, Ed --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he'd be at the gas station at six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, this job takes me to some of the best damn places, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin is sitting out front, swigging cough syrup from the bottle.  She checks her watch: 6:30.  The GAS STATION ATTENDANT comes out, locks up, and turns out the lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the only station in town, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup. He gets in his car and drives off.  Erin sits down again. Looks down the road in both directions.  Nothing. Then she spots, behind some bushes across the street, a g of chrome.  She shields her eyes against the sunset and s the BEAT-UP TRUCK parked behind some shrubbery. Erin looks around, realizes she's alone.  As she looks ba at the truck, the ASH of a cigarette brightens in the cab She realizes she's being watched.  The driver's door open Erin bolts for her car, scrambling to find her keys.  She jumps in, locks her doors, and tries to start her car, bu won't turn over.  Panic.  The Man in the Dark Glasses has gotten out and is heading toward her car. Erin looks arou again.  Not a soul.  She tries the engine again.  And aga Just as he gets to her car, the engine engages.  Erin pee out of the gas station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin drives down the road, hyperventilating, trying to fo on the road.  She looks in the rear-view mirror -- nothin She reaches the train tracks.  A train is passing.  She h to stop.  As she's waiting, the glint of headlights bounc off her rear view mirror.  Truck lights, coming her way. Fuck.  She looks at the train -- still passing -- then ba at the headlights closing in on her.  The train, the headlights, the train, the headlights ... Finally, when the headlights are right behind her, the la train car zips by.  Erin peels out, bounding her rickety over the tracks.  The truck follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hyundai zips down the road.  And behind it, the truck

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks out at the landscape around her.  It's black. other cars on the road.  She starts to panic, accelerates

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hyundai going faster.  The truck still following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin comes up on a stop sign.  She runs it.  So does the truck.   A little later, she makes a turn and sees THE LO CAUSE SALOON.  In the parking lot, like a lifeboat, sits Mercedes.  She pulls into the drive and jumps out of her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed is eating ribs when Erin bursts through the door.  She rushes over to him, near tears with fear and exhaustion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone's following me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some guy in a truck -- he waited till I was alone, then he followed me, like, two miles. Jesus, I'm shaking.  Get me a beer. Ed gets up and heads toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the counter guy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beer, please. As Ed looks out the door, Erin collapses onto a bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of truck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Big.  Dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gone. (back to the table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get a license plate?  Or a make?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Ed -- what with me running for my life, I didn't have time to check those things --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just asking.  Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Yeah, I'm ... fine. Ed looks at her.  She looks terrible.  Shaky, tired, draw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, you look like shit.  When was the last time you had a decent night's sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crappy and pink.  Ed's Mercedes pulls into the parking lo Erin's Hyundai follows.  Ed stops, gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed swings by Erin's open car window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.  I'm getting two rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin and Ed amble down the porch, checking door numbers, rattling a key.  They find their adjacent rooms and stop. Erin leans against the wall, too weak to stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lock the door every which way you can.  And if there's anything -- funny sound, whatever -- pound on the wall.  I'll come right over. She nods a little.  Then before she goes into her room:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should know -- there's very few people in the world who don't piss me off 90 percent of the time. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're one of 'em. It's as tender as she gets, and he's moved by it.  They l at each other.  Maybe even considering.  But after a long beat, she reaches for her door again.  Moment over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm triple locking my door, so don't even think of trying to take advantage. She smiles, goes inside.  He watches her close her door behind her before going inside himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is sitting alone on the stoop, drinking a beer.  M is coming from his house next door.  He stares out into t street with a lot on his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie and Matt are making a mess of breakfast.  Beth is o the floor, grinding cereal into the linoleum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Erin enters, having just gotten home, and sees the mayhem

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?  Where's George?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George! She heads out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is sitting on the bed when Erin enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, George, they're turning the kitchen into a hellhole.  You know you can't leave them alone like that. He doesn't answer.  Doesn't move.  She notices this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?  What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what? He's very calm.  He holds out a small jewelry box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a pair of earrings.  I saw 'em in the mall one day, and I thought, damn, those would look good on those beautiful earlobes. So I bought 'em.  And I said to myself, next time Erin says something nice, does something nice, I'll surprise her with 'em. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know how long ago that was?  Six months.  In six months, you haven't said one nice thing to me.  That's a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  I'm just working so hard --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  But still.  Six months. (he stands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you oughta either find a different job or a different boyfriend.  Cause there may be men who don't mind being the maid and getting nothing in return, but I'm sure as shit not one of 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't leave my job, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you can.  You could just quit.  People do it all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.  Look -- this job -- it's the best thing that ever happened to me.  I mean it. For the first time in my life, I got people respecting me.  Up in Hinkley, I walk into a room and everyone shuts up just to hear what I got to say.  I never had that.  Ever. Don't ask me to give it up.  I need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More than you need me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need it. He nods, then stands, to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you didn't like who you were before, Erin, but I did.  That's who I fell in love with. Only then does she see the packed duffel bag in the corne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already packed up your stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pretty much knew what your answer was gonna be. He picks it up and walks out the door, tossing the earrin box on the bed as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin is at her window, looking out at the street below. George is strapping a couple of bags onto the back of his bike.  He gets on the bike, starts it up, and drives away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin is driving, looking weary.  Her kids are in the car. Matthew turns on the radio.  Erin reaches over and turns off.  Matthew turns it back on.  Erin glares at him, turn off.  On/off/on/off.  A test of wills.  Finally, when Mat turns it on one more time, Erin turns it off, yanks the k off the stereo and throws it out the window. EXT. MASRY & VITITOE PARKING LOT - DAY The Hyundai pulls into the lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin parks the car, unclips her seat belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait here. She gets out. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, MAIN ROOM - DAY Business as usual.  Erin comes in, goes straight to her d INT. MASRY & VITITOE, ERIN'S DESK - DAY Erin flips through her "in" box, looking for something in particular.  Doesn't find it.  Grrr.  She heads off to: INT. MASRY & VITITOE, JANE'S OFFICE - DAY Jane is at her desk when Erin comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my paycheck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been logging on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I moved payroll onto the computer.  It only knows to process paychecks for employees who log on in the morning and off at night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seething)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now how'm I supposed to do that when I'm not in here most mornings and nights?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're clever.  I'm sure you'll think of something. Erin glares at her ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe this -- ... then turns and storms out of Jane's office. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, ED'S OFFICE - DAY Ed is on the phone when Erin barges in, rage in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want my fucking money --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I'm gonna have to put you on hold for just one second here -- (puts the call on hold, then, to Erin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seething)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I mind.  You bet your ass I mind. Clearly, she's in a dander he's going to have to deal wit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus.  You wanna tell me what the problem is here, or --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my paycheck.  Which I earned.  Which I deserve.  Which I shouldn't have to beg for. That fat-ass bitch won't give it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin, you're a big girl.  If you got a problem with Jane, work it out for yourself. I don't have time to deal with --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.  Make time.  Cause I bust my ass for you.  I watch everything else in my life go straight in the toilet, for you.  And what do you do for me?  Huh?  You see the way I'm treated around here -- but have you ever stood up for me once?  Have you ever mentioned to everyone what good work I'm doing?  Have you ever bothered saying, hey, Erin doesn't get paid the most cause she has the best tits; she gets paid the most cause she's the best God damn employee I've ever had?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want my paycheck.  By the end of the day. Ed sighs.  Realizes he's going to have to take this on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see what I can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might want to think real hard about the amount, too.  My kids are sitting in the God damn parking lot right now, cause I still don't make enough to afford good child care. Makes me think about looking around for a job where I'm appreciated, for shit's sake. She storms out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin is standing at the sink, visibly exhausted, trying t the dinner dishes with one arm and comfort Beth, who's CRYING, with the other.  Matthew comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I play roller hockey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When? The DOORBELL RINGS.  Erin goes to get it.  Matthew follow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matthew is dogging Erin on this.  Beth is still crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy's mom said yes right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snapping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, God damn it, Matthew -- Randy's mom doesn't work eighteen-hour days, and Randy's dad didn't leave her, so figuring out who's gonna take who where is a little easier over at Randy's house. Erin opens the door.  A MESSENGER is there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin Brockovich?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Package from Masry & Vititoe. He hands her a manila envelope.  She signs for the packag then tears into it as the Messenger heads away. A CHECK and a SET OF KEYS fall out.  She looks at the che It's made out for $5,000.  A note attached reads "HIRE A

dialogues.speaker: NANNY. AND LOOK OUTSIDE.
dialogues.text: Erin looks up and sees A BRAND-NEW CHEVY BLAZER parked on curb.  She looks at the keys in her hand.  Chevy keys.  W EXT. MASRY & VITITOE, PARKING LOT - DAY Erin drives up in the Blazer, pulls into a parking space. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, LAW LIBRARY - DAY It's dark.  Ed's seated at a table, alone.  Erin walks by door, then spots him and stops in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe it or not, I would've been satisfied with just the check. Ed turns, sees her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you go threatening to leave, I can't take any chances.  You're the only person around who understands what I'm doing. Things come up, I gotta know I got someone to turn to. She sits, reading him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of things come up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things like the head counsel for PG&E calling me with an offer. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 million, plus attorney's fees.  Take it or leave it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa.  No shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about 50 thousand per plaintiff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking ... I wish someone else had to make this decision. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 thousand bucks is more than any other California toxic plaintiff has gotten. Ever.  But ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but it won't cover Annabelle Daniels's medical bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's less than pocket change for PG&E.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think we'd do better by going to trial?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.  but maybe not.  We still don't have anything linking this to PG&E corporate. Plus, there's the statute problem.  Plus, we're way short on manpower, so we'd need to bring on more lawyers ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plus, 40 percent of 20 million's a whole lot of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's eight million dollars, Erin.  Eight million dollars. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a fucking fortune, Ed.  And you know I'm the last person on Earth to walk away from a big payday.  But you and me didn't get into this to get rich.  We did it cause we both have this voice in our heads saying, do the right thing; get these plaintiffs what they deserve -- the right to live and die in some kind of comfort and peace.  If 50,000 isn't gonna buy that, then we gotta say no. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me.  If you don't do the right thing for these people, getting that 6 million dollars is gonna feel like shit. He nods to himself, and looks up at her, his mind made up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew I put up with your bullshit for a reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's raining.  They're driving through the tall buildings Century City.  Ed is full of nervous excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy, Erin -- he's got more toxic tort experience than anyone else in California. He's huge.  And he said yes to me on the first phone call, right off the bat. (points to a building)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it.  The big one.  They've got the top three floors. INT. POTTER, HUGHES & ROSEWOOD, RECEPTION - DAY It feels more like the lobby of a five-star hotel than an office.  Erin and Ed step off the elevator.  Erin gawks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit.  Who do they represent, God?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't joke.  They might.  So do me a favor and behave yourself for once. (to receptionist)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Masry to see Kurt Potter. As Ed turns to check his reflection, a YOUNG LAWYER comes through the reception area.  Erin watches him pass, then, still miffed, calls out to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scuse me, sir, you got a real nice ass, you know that? The lawyer double-takes on her, then retreats into the office.  Erin turns to Ed, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry.  Was that not what you meant by behaving myself? INT. POTTER, HUGHES & ROSEWOOD RECEPTION AREA - DAY THERESA DELLAVALLE, 38, junior partner, comes out to gree them.  She's everything Erin isn't: conservative, restrai unemotional.  And about as sexy as a station wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed.  Good to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theresa, hey -- this is Erin Brockovich. INT. POTTER, HUGHES & ROSEWOOD HALLWAY - DAY Theresa leads Ed and Erin down a long hall of teak desks. The sound of their footfalls is swallowed up by the plush carpeting.  Occasional ATTORNEYS and PARALEGALS glance at Erin.  She feels their stares. INT. POTTER, HUGHES & ROSEWOOD, KURT POTTER'S OFFICE Potter is sitting behind his giant desk when Theresa lead and Erin in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kurt, Ed Masry's here.  And this is Erin Brockovich, Ed's assistant.  Erin, this is Kurt Potter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ed, with a wink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  Now I know what you meant when you called her your secret weapon. Erin gives Ed another look.  What the fuck?  Ed gives her firm look back.  Behave. INT. POTTER, HUGHES & ROSEWOOD, CONFERENCE ROOM - DAY Potter, Ed, Erin, Theresa and few  PARALEGALS are sitting around the table.  As the conversation ping-pongs between and Potter, Potter completely ignores Erin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When'd they file the demur?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a demur?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's PG&E saying to the judge that we don't have a case.  Their lawyers go --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many counts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixty-nine.  We've got good answers to all of 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Counts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reasons PG&E thinks it shouldn't go to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the judge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a reputation for doing all his --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long's he gonna take? Erin's starting to steam at Potter.  Theresa sees it brew tries to intercede.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what?  Why don't I take Erin down the hall, so we can start in on this stuff? Erin notices all her files in stacks against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- those are my files --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we had them couriered over.  And listen, good work.  They're a great start. We're just going to have to spend a little time filling in the holes in your research. Okay, these people are starting to piss her off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me -- Theresa, was it?  There are no holes in my research.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No offense.  There are just some things we need that you probably didn't know to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk to me like I'm an idiot, okay?  I may not have a law degree, but I've spent 18 months on this case, and I know more about those plaintiffs than you ever will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin.  You don't even have phone numbers for some of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose number do you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone's.  This is a lawsuit.  We need to be able to contact the plaintiffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, whose number do you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know six hundreds plaintiffs' numbers by heart. Erin just stares at her.  Theresa sighs, reluctantly glan down at a file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annabelle Daniels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annabelle Daniels.  714-454-9346. As Theresa starts to write it down:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 years old, 11 in May.  Lived on the plume since birth.  Wanted to be a synchronized swimmer, so she spent every minute she could in the PG&E pool.  She had a tumor in her brain stem detected last November, had an operation on Thanksgiving, shrunk it with radiation after that.  Her parents are Rita and Ted.  Ted's got Chron's disease, and Rita has chronic headaches and nausea and underwent a hysterectomy last fall.  Ted grew up in Hinkley.  His brother Robbie and his wife May and their five kids Robbie, Jr., Martha, Ed, Rose, and Peter lived on the plume too.  Their number's 454-9445. You want their diseases? Beat.  Erin glares at Theresa, indignant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, look -- I think we got off on the wrong foot here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all you got, lady.  Two wrong feet. In fucking ugly shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's still raining.  Erin is following Ed to the car.  He furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She insulted me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit.  It was a misunderstanding.  But instead of handling it politely, instead of treating her with respect --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the fuck should I respect her? Ed stops in his tracks, furious.  He glares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because that's how people treat each other!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in my world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, I wonder why. On that, he gets in his car, slams the door, and drives o leaving her standing alone in the pouring rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  You're my ride! INT. POTTER, HUGHES & ROSEWOOD, HALLWAY - DAY Potter and Ed are walking down the hallway, mid-conversat A FEW PARALEGALS follow them with files.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've also been thinking about the team. Responsibilities, who should cover what --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we should makes some changes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob Linwood is in his barn, mucking it out.  Theresa is a the edge of the property, trying unsuccessfully to get hi attention by yelling and waving her arms.
