In her expensi shoes, she's stopped short of the cow patty minefield. INT. POTTER, HUGHES & ROSEWOOD, CONFERENCE ROOM - DAY CLOSE ON A CLIENT FILE as a hand fills in a phone number. WIDEN TO SEE Erin seated with a PARALEGAL, rattling off f and numbers from memory.  She's seized by a COUGHING FIT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theresa still hasn't gotten Linwood's attention.  Finally rather than ruin her shoes, she picks up a stone and toss it at the barn.  It hits the window and BREAKS IT. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, ERIN AND BRENDA'S DESKS - DAY Erin's desk is empty: no Erin, no files, nothing.  Ed com out of his office and hands Brenda a STACK OF DOCUMENTS.

dialogues.speaker: THE FAX LED
dialogues.text: Brenda types in the number.  The recipient's I.D. comes u again, only this time it says: POTTER, HUGHES, ROSEWOOD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SECRETARY carries the documents to Potter's office.  On way, she passes THE CONFERENCE ROOM.  Inside, Erin is sti dictating to the PARALEGAL.  She's shivery with fever now The floor around her is littered with tissues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theresa is talking to Rita and Ted Daniels.  Annabelle is curled up on the sofa, wrapped up in a blanket.  Rita and notice that Theresa doesn't even look at Annabelle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin is lying in bed, home sick, talking on the phone.  S talking over the noise of TANIA, her 20-something Eastern European nanny, vacuuming the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know she isn't real warm, but they say she's a real good lawyer ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted Daniels is on the phone.  Rita is next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That may be.  But I don't want her coming to the house again.  She's kinda stuck-up, and she upsets Annabelle.  Now, I hate to say this, but when she left today, Rita asked if we should get a new lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, no -- don't do that.  If you don't like Theresa, you don't have to work with her. Me and Ed are still here for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called Ed two days ago, Erin, and he still hasn't called me back. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, BRENDA'S DESK - DAY The phone rings.  Brenda picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Masry's office ... Sorry, he can't be interrupted. INTERCUT WITH Erin at home, still in bed, so irritated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be a pain in the ass, okay, Brenda? Just put him on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with finality)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, he can't be interrupted. Erin hangs up.  Then, with a groan, she pulls her weary b out of bed. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, RECEPTION - DAY Erin drags herself into the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Erin, I thought you were taking a sick day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So did I. She heads toward Ed's office, but stops when she sees a meeting in progress in the conference room.  Ed is on the side of the table facing her, flanked by Potter and There On the other side of the table, are FOUR SUITED BACKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some meeting.  With PG&E people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PG& -- Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup.  They must be important, too, cause they came on a special plane. Erin feels this like a sock in the gut.  She stares at th meeting, stunned. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, CONFERENCE ROOM - DAY This band of PG&E lawyers is the oldest and most impr of all.  Ed, Potter, and Theresa are listening to the mos senior PG&E lawyer, MR. CORBIN, talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... we would enter into binding arbitration -- judge, no jury -- with a settlement to be between 50 and 400 million dollars. Ed and Potter hear this and think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any preconditions on the settlements?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plaintiffs have to agree to it unanimously.  And they're barred from ever discussing their settlement with anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50-400 million dollars isn't a whole hell of a lot of money for your company, Mr. Corbin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50-400 million dollars is a great deal of money for your plaintiffs, Mr. Masry. As Ed mulls this, he sees, beyond Mr. Corbin,

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: staring at him from the other side of the glass wall, her face cold with hurt and anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I -- just take a brief break here for a moment?  I'll be right back. He gets up and goes out into: INT. MASRY & VITITOE, MAIN ROOM - DAY Ed comes out.  Erin's so angry she can barely breathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you tell me to relax, I'm gonna kick your fucking head off --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin, it's just a meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People don't fly down in their own god damn plane for "just a meeting" --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you said you weren't feeling great.  I thought you should rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit.  You'd drag me off my deathbed if it suited you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, look.  It's an important meeting. Kurt thought, if it was just lawyers --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kurt thought?  What about you?  Do you think anymore? He resists being dragged into an knock-down, drag-out fig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, this is serious now.  They're talking serious money --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, what, I'm not serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're emotional.  You're erratic.  You say any God damn thing that comes into your head.  And I'm not saying that's bad.  That can be great; that can be a lot of fun --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Fun?"  Jesus, "fun?"  I kill myself for a year and a half, hand you the best case of your life on a God damn silver platter, remind you of why you became a lawyer in the first place, and you think of me as "fun?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, now you're making this personal, and it isn't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not personal?  That's my work in there, Ed. My sweat, my labor, my time.  If that's not personal, I don't know what is. She starts to COUGH and CRUMBLE, but fights it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakened)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare you take that away from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's taking anything --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit.  You stuck me in Siberia dictating to some God damn steno clerk so you could finish this thing without me.  After all I've done for you, that's the thanks I get. By now the entire office is watching.  As are the lawyers the conference room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give me that.  You've gotten plenty. You've been well-paid; you've gotten lots of perks ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perks?  Jesus -- perks? Erin reaches into her bag, pulls out her cel phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this piece of shit is supposed to take the place of your respect, you can take it and shove it up your ass. She throws it at him and storms away.  The phone hits the glass wall of the conference room, CRACKING it.  Ed just stands there, with the lawyers staring at him through the splintered glass wall. EXT. MASRY & VITITOE PARKING LOT - DAY Erin gets to her car.  As she opens the door, the ALARM SOUNDS.  She fumbles with her keychain, trying to turn it off, but she's too sick and upset to figure it out.  With siren still blaring, she kicks at the car in rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin's driving home.  As she turns onto her street, her headlights wash across the sidewalk and illuminate a smal boy, wearing a backpack, walking the other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit -- She looks over her shoulder, but the sidewalk is too dark She pulls a U-turn in the middle of the street.  A CAR HO Erin scans the sidewalk, finally sees him again.  Holy sh is right.  It's Matthew, wandering the streets at night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matthew -- She pulls ahead of Matthew and bumps up onto the sidewalk blocking his path.  When he sees her car, he turns and ru the other way.  Erin leaps out and follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matthew!  MATTHEW! She catches up and collars him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn it, Matthew.  What the hell are you doing out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna go live with George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC is playing.  TANIA is on the phone.  The receiver i yanked from her hand.  She turns to see Erin hovering ove her, barely containing herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you leave here real fast, I might not kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matthew's in his bed, facing the wall.  Erin sitting on t foot of his bed, near tears.  Katie's watching from her b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll work out the roller hockey thing, okay?  Whatever you want, we'll work it out. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always say that.  Then you go to work and forget you promised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never forget, honey.  I try, real hard. It's just, for some reason, I don't seem to be able to organize things right and -- when it comes to you guys, I end up falling short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never fall short for the work people.  I guess maybe you just love them more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God, sweetheart, no.  There's nothing on Earth I love more than you.  Nothing. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise. She lays her hand on his shoulder, but he shrugs it off a inches away from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin comes out of the bedroom.  As she turns to close the door, she collapses to the floor in a heap.  Out cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A busy Southland ER.  George bursts through the doors wit Katie, Matthew and Beth in tow.  He goes up to the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for Erin Brockovich.  They brought her in in an ambulance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids are waiting.  George is talking to a DOCTOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meningitis?  What the hell is meningitis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an inflammation of the spinal cord and part of the brain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She must be a tough cookie, cause it's a pretty advanced case.  I'd say she's been walking around with it for a few weeks now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does someone get meningitis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Usually, in adults, it's from exposure to bacteria or a virus or ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... or lemme guess -- toxic waste?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt and Katie sit on the cheap plastic chairs outside th room.  Katie is holding Beth, who's sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can stay at my place till you go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin's in bed, hooked up to an IV, looking exhausted.  Al untouched food tray is beside her bed.  George is standin across the room from her, arms crossed tight across his chest, keeping his distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said that'd be tomorrow.  They just wanna keep an eye on me another night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.  I'll drop 'em off tomorrow afternoon. A moment of thick silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving nothing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-hm. As she watches him reach for his motorcycle helmet, to le she's hit with a wave of regret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, hang on. (he pauses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look ... I'm sorry.  I just -- There's a KNOCK at the door, and Ed enters.  George looks him.  Not interested in her apologies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll drop 'em by tomorrow. And Erin watches George leave the room, then turns to Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're here to fire me, your timing's lousy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna fire you. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to.  But then you got sick, and that woulda made me look like a shit. (serious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You embarrassed me, Erin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  I'm sorry. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I get to hear what happened anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed has taken off his coat and pulled a chair up next to Erin's bed.  He's eating the pudding off her tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between 50 and 400 million, definitely?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you had to guess ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With nothing linking it to the corporate offices yet, I'd say we'll end up on the lower end of that.  Still a lot of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why would PG&E offer it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because.  They know the evidence; they know they're gonna lose a jury trial.  Maybe they wouldn't lose 400 million bucks, but once you factor in all they'd spend on this case in the next ten years, it makes a lot of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, what do you mean, ten years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five years, maybe, for a trial.  Double that for the appeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, are you saying that if this thing goes to trial, it'll be ten years before these plaintiffs see their money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, that's not so bad.  Compare it to the Love Canal -- that was twenty years ago, and those people still haven't seen a dime.  So in legal terms, ten years is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck legal terms.  We're talking about human beings here.  Sick people.  A whole bunch of them are gonna be dead in ten years.  They need their money now! (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta get 'em to agree to the arbitration, Ed.  We gotta get every damn one of those plaintiffs to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  We're having a meeting, it's all set up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?  Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuesday at seven, at the Hinkley firehouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, good.  I think I should be the one to tell 'em, cause they trust me more than --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not gonna be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fuck I'm not.  I don't care what the doctor says --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't doctor's orders.  It's mine.  I'm saying you can't come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because Kurt doesn't want to work with you. He thinks you're a loose cannon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck Kurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm serious.  You know what Kurt Potter is?  He's the kind of guy who never would have taken this case in the first place. He's the kind of guy who would have sold these plaintiffs down the river when PG&E offered 20 million.  He doesn't work like us, Ed.  There's no little voice in his head telling him to do the right thing. But his mind's made up.  He stands to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't come, Erin.  I mean it.  If you do, I'm gonna have to fire you. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just ... concentrate on getting well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The parking lot is empty, except for three Mercedes.  Ed, Potter, and Theresa are in the doorway, going over their notes.  A TRUCK pulls into the lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie and Matt are watching TV.  Beth is playing near the Behind them, Erin is lying on the couch, under a blanket, distractedly trying to watch TV.  She checks her watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lot is filling with more cars and trucks; headlights criss-cross each other as people pull in from all directi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin's sitting up now, jiggling her knee, unable to sit still.  She checks her watch again.  6:30.  She can't tak it.  She throws off the blanket and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, kids, we're going for a ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON HANDS.  As people stream in, they are each hande release form with a space for a signature on the bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's sweltering.  The room, packed with plaintiffs, hums horse flies and tension.  People are fanning themselves w the release forms.  Potter's addressing them from a raise platform.  Ed, Theresa, and Andrew are seated behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Binding arbitration isn't all that different from a trial.  It's overseen by a judge. Evidence is presented in much the same way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more car pulls into the lot.  It's Erin's Chevy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin unbuckles her seat belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay in the car, babies, I won't be long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin gets out of the car, looks around, then goes over to window and looks in at the packed meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then a jury decides?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sorry, I should have mentioned that. There's no jury in binding arbitration.  No jury, and no appeal. She climbs up on an old wagon for a better view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No appeal?  So what are our options if we don't like the result?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- you have none.  The judge's decision is final.  But I really don't anticipate that as a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, in addition to the stifling heat, the large room is thick with mistrust.  People are shifting in their seats, whispering to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't even know what it's gonna be; how do you know we're gonna like it? Agreeing MURMURS ripple through the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I said before, it will definitely be somewhere between 50 and 400 million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which?  There's a big difference there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't want to speculate at this point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed -- what do you think it'll be? Potter turns around and looks at Ed seated behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think ... Kurt's right.  We shouldn't speculate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So then, what, that mystery number's divided up at the whim of some judge --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judges don't make decisions based on whim, ma'am.  They make them based on precedent and evidence. The GRUMBLE of discontent has overtaken the room.  More whispering, more movement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin watches the meeting fall apart.  It's driving her cr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking idiot --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Potter sees he's losing them, too.  Tries to gain control

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look.  Everyone.  Is this a big decision? Absolutely.  But I do believe that if you put a little faith in the system, you'll be quite pleased with the outcome. Ted Daniels gets up from his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Potter, if you knew me from Adam, you'd know that being pleased isn't an option for me anymore.  Now don't take this personally, sir, but I've never seen you before in my life.  I'm not about to put my faith in anything just cause you tell me to. He drops his agreement form, unsigned, then takes Rita's and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meeting's over.  The plaintiffs stream out of the firehou Cars start up, headlights flick on.  People pull away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone has left.  Erin enters and looks around.  The fl is littered with rejected, unsigned release forms. She thinks for a moment, then gets an idea.  She picks up release form, and leaves the firehouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's closed, except the KINKO'S store at the far Erin's truck pulls into the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BORED EMPLOYEE is at the register, painting with Wite-O on a blue piece of paper.  Erin enters, dragging her kids

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have one of those counter thingies, please? The Employee gives it to her.  Erin crosses to the copier She slips the release form into one, then taps in the num of copies: 635.  Presses "START."  The machine WHIRS to l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin's Chevy pulls into the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to stay here.  It smells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin is entering the crappy motel room with her kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got no choice.  I'm not gonna make it home tonight.  Now go wash up and climb into bed. As the kids wander toward the bathroom, Erin picks up the phone and dials.  RING, RING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.  It's me. (silence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a favor to ask you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't do favors for you anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not for me; it's for my kids.  You're the only one I trust them with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very early.  Erin is visible in the motel office, talking the clerk, when George's motorcycle pulls into the lot. turns around and sees him pulling up next to her Chevy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin comes up to him, hands him a key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got you your own room. He takes it, glances toward the motel room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunh-uh.  Not yet. (awkward beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, don't take any of 'em on your bike, okay?  Call a cab if you wanna go somewhere. She hands him a wad of cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long's this whole thing gonna take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Few days. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for helping me.  I appreciate it. He nods.  She gets into her car.  Before closing the door she turns back to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I miss you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well -- good help is hard to find. She sees how mad she's made him.  Takes a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I treated you real bad, George.  I know that.  But, my problem was -- I never been with anyone who deserved better than that. You're the first nice guy who ever liked me. George softens, shifts.  He steps toward the truck and ge closes her door, so he's standing close to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just ... didn't know how to handle it. That's all. He thinks about this.  Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think you could learn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know me.  I pick things up real fast. He smiles back at her, nods, then tenderly brushes a piec hair out of her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be driving around, you know. You're sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I'm gonna get better.  A lot of these folks aren't. He nods, understanding.  Then he taps the side of her tru and turns toward the motel room.  She puts the truck in g and pulls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin's Chevy is bombing down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are two boxes there -- one full of unsigned release forms, the other empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna's gardening out front, her head wrapped in a scarf cover her chemo-thinning hair, when Erin's Chevy pulls in the driveway.  Erin gets out, goes to the back of the tru gets two of the release forms, then heads over to Donna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin is sitting with Pete and Donna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Erin -- the way he was talking to us, telling us everything was gonna be fine -- I just didn't trust him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And after all we been through -- no jury, no appeal.  It just makes me nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand all that. And I don't wanna force you into anything.  If you don't want to sign, that's fine.  But why don't we talk it over a little, cause I'd sure hate for you to turn this down for the wrong reasons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens.  Erin emerges, holding two signed agreeme Donna is letting her out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't happen to have a little time right now, would you, Donna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I was gonna head over to the Browns now.  I was thinking -- Mandy really values your opinion ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin, Donna, Mandy, and Tom are seated on the sofas.  Man signs an agreement.  Hands the pen to Tom, who also signs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From outside, we see Erin at the kitchen table with Donna Bob and Ruth Linwood, who are listening intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin and Donna are leaving, saying good-bye to Mary DeSot Erin has a signed release form in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DISCO blares.  The two boxes.  The formerly empty one now a small stack of signed release forms in it.  The top one Bob Linwood's signature.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE FRONT SEAT
dialogues.text: Erin is driving, eating a hamburger, and going over her l of plaintiffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are going about their shopping.  Rita Daniels is stopped, talking with A FEW MORE PLAINTIFFS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought so, too, but Erin says a trial's gonna take years

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The signed stack has grown; the unsigned stack has shrunk Erin drops five more agreements into the "signed" box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the wee hours.  While her kids sleep, Erin sits at the cheap motel room table, going through her forms, organizi alphabetizing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON ERIN, fast asleep at the table, her face pressed against the linoleum.  There's some NOISE in the room, WHISPERING.  Erin stirs and looks around to see George be her, diapering Beth, while Matt and Katie put their shoes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real early.  We're just gonna take your car to get some breakfast. Erin forces herself awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I need my car --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll just be a minute.  Get a little more sleep. He picks up Beth, takes Katie's hand, and calls across th room to Matthew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, pal.  Leave that alone, we gotta go. Erin turns to see Matthew holding one of her release form

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, baby, please don't play with that, okay? I got 'em all organized.  Just put it back. But he's reading it.  And something has caught his attent He looks up at Erin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This girl's the same age as me. Erin gently takes the form away from Matthew, wanting to shield him from the harsh realities of this case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, sweetheart. She replaces the form on top of the stack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's one of the sick people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  She is. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you know what?  That's why I'm helping her.  So she can get some medicine to make her feel better. Matthew mulls this over a bit more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come her own mom isn't helping her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause her own mom's real sick, too. Matthew thinks real hard about this, then heads over to t door, where George, Beth, and Katie are waiting for him. Before he leaves, though, he turns back to Erin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we'll bring you back some breakfast. You want eggs? She looks at the group of them, feels their shift toward acceptance.  Smiles, moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eggs'd be great, baby.  Eggs'd be perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin's driving along a dusty Hinkley road, eating cold eg out of a take-out container with her fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning.  A GROUP OF MEN are arriving at work.  Erin's tr pulls up.  She grabs some release forms from the truck an wanders up to the men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, y'all.  How you all doing today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tosses eight more agreements in the signed stack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning drop-off time.  Erin is handing out release forms a GROUP of MOTHERS who just dropped off their kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin is leaning on the hood of her truck, going down her of plaintiffs, checking off the ones who have already sig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another day.  Erin has set up shop here and is at a table with about FIVE PLAINTIFFS, all reading agreements.  MIKE AMBROSINO enters.  Erin spots him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike!  I been looking all over for you. Come here, I wanna talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The signed stack is getting bigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And bigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And still bigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON ERIN'S TRUNK.  A bunch more forms get thrown ont the signed stack, which is now much higher than the unsig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna head out to Barstow and talk to some folks out there tonight. WIDEN TO REVEAL Erin talking on a nearby pay phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise you'll turn around if you get tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will.  Bye. She hangs up.  As she turns to get into her car, she find herself face-to-face with the Man in the Dark Glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus! He's just standing there, a foot away, blocking her exit. She recognizes his truck as the one that chased her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, what're you gonna do?  You gonna kill me?  Dump my body in a ditch somewhere?  Or maybe you just wanna inject me with some poison too -- why change tactics at this stage of the game? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get outta my way, you make me sick. She pushes past him.  But he grabs her by the arm.  He's big guy; it's a strong grab.  Now she's scared.  For a moment, he does nothing.  Just looks at her.  Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If PG&E made someone destroy a whole lot of documents -- would that matter to you? Erin takes a beat, realizing she completely misread him. gently pulls her arm away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ... I guess that depends on what the documents were. (she takes a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry -- I didn't get your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Embry.  Charles Embry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin and Embry are the only patrons.  Erin's eating a bur Embry has a beer.  He's talking quietly, not looking at h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was working in the compressor, and out of nowhere the supervisor calls me up to the office and says, we're gonna give you a shredder machine, and send you on down to the warehouse.  We want you to get rid of all the documents stored out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he say why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.  And I didn't ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get a look at the stuff you destroyed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's pretty boring work, shredding -- you gotta find some way to entertain your mind.  So yeah, I took a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And ...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a lot of dull stuff -- vacation schedules, the like. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then there were a few memos about the holding ponds.  The water in them.  They had readings from test wells, stuff like that. Erin tries to hide her excitement at this information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you were told to destroy those?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Destruction of evidence.  Pretty big deal.  Erin plays it down.  Wipes her mouth with her napkin, takes a sip of be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course as it turns out, I'm not a very good employee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  There were a few documents that I somehow didn't get around to shredding. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I kept instead. Erin stops, mid-bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dug out an inch-high stack of documents.  Erin looks them over, stunned.  Embry is standing apart from her, ha shoved deep in his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you didn't say anything when you found these things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the time, I thought, I got six kids, some of 'em want to go to college.  I can't afford to lose my job.  I told myself I was being honorable. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there's nothing honorable in what I did. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe that's why they picked me for the job. Maybe they knew what kind of man I was. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, RECEPTION AREA - DAY Rosalind is at the desk.  Anna, Brenda, and Jane are help themselves to coffee.  Erin enters, with a big box in her arms and a whole lot of attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ros, where are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the conference -- But Erin's spotted them and headed off before Rosalind ca finish.  Anna, Brenda and Jane notice the purpose in her gait.  They watch her with interest. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, CONFERENCE ROOM - DAY The table is covered with boxes of documents: the anticip slew of paper that PG&E is sending them.  Ed, Kurt, T Andrew and ABOUT FIVE PARALEGALS are sifting through them Erin breezes in like sunshine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin?  What are you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring Ed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what, Mr. Potter?  I completely forgot your birthday this year.  And seeing as how you've been so good to me, I think that is a terrible oversight.  So what I been doing over the last few days is I've been putting together a present for you. She plunks the box down on the table.  Potter opens the t of the box.  Looks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 635.  They all signed.  Every single one. IN THE DOORWAY, Anna, Brenda and Jane appear, wondering what's up.  A huge smile of appreciation slowly spreads across Ed's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ho - ly - shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, now don't get all jealous, Ed.  I got a little something for you, too. Erin hands Ed a manila envelope.  He opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Internal PG&E documents, all about the contamination.  The one I like best says, and I'm paraphrasing here, but it says yes, the water's poisonous, but it'd be better for all involved if this matter wasn't discussed with the neighbors.  It's to the Hinkley station, from PG&E Headquarters. Stamped received, March, 1966. Potter and Theresa reel.  Ed shakes his head in disbelief

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did -- how did you do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what with me not having any brains or legal expertise, I just went on up there and performed sexual favors.  635 blow jobs in five days.  Whew, am I ever tired. And she struts out of the room, leaving everyone slack-ja The CLIP CLIP CLIP of her heels carry her away. EXT. MASRY & VITITOE BUILDING, HALLWAY - DAY Erin comes out of the office, flushed with success, and h down the hall.  She presses the elevator button.  The doo open.  As she steps on, Ed comes out of the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Erin puts her hand in the door, keeping it from closing. stares at her, in awe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say you were wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say you shortchanged me and you shortchanged yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.  Both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say you'd be the luckiest son of a bitch on Earth if I didn't up and quit over all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The luckiest son of a bitch in the universe, Erin.  The luckiest son of a bitch in history. He looks down the hall at her, standing so tall and proud the elevator.  He walks toward her, stops right outside t elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I know you're not gonna quit on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause you got a little voice in your head saying, do the right thing.  Give him another chance. Of course she will.  She releases her hand so he won't se her smiling.  Ed watches the doors close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of those days when the bay sparkles like a glitter ba Erin's Chevy moves up the PCH.  DISCO music emanates from

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin's at the wheel.  Time has passed -- her hair's a lit different.  She's singing along with "Funky Town."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin gets out of her new truck, looks, sees the Irvings i little cluster.  Donna's under an umbrella.  Pete is slathering on sunscreen.  The two girls zip out toward th water.  Erin waves.  Pete and Donna spot her, wave back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna is standing at the edge of the water, watching her girls boogie board in.  Erin comes up behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you feeling today? Donna turns, sees her.  Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a good day.  I feel good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then -- if you're feeling up to it, maybe we should talk shop. Erin sits down on a rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The judge came up with a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A number for the whole group, or for us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both. Donna sits down next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's making them pay the maximum. Tears of vindication spring to Donna's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's making them give five million of it to you all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five million dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five million dollars. She reels.  After a breathless beat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even know how much money that is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's enough -- for whatever you need, for whatever your girls need, for whatever your girls' girls need -- it'll be enough. Donna wipes the tears off her face, then watches the ligh flickering off her girls playing in the surf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can put them in a good school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any school you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And get someone to help around the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God.  Oh my God. Donna is overwhelmed.  Erin pulls her close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my God. EXT. MASRY & VITITOE'S NEW OFFICE BUILDING - DAY Now this is where the hot lawyers work.  A gleaming testa to power. INT. MASRY & VITITOE'S NEW OFFICE - DAY Boxes everywhere.  They just moved in.  Everyone is unpac at his or her desk.  Rosalind is manning the new phones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masry & Vititoe, can I -- shoot! She lost them.  Her reaction indicates this isn't the fir time.  The front doors open and Erin enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ros.  Nice view, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm gonna start sleeping here. (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masry & Vititoe, can I -- damn it. (calling out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does anyone know anything about these phones? Erin heads on down a hall to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful corner office.  Ed is unpacking when Erin ent

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful you don't spit from here; you could kill someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see your office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Yours is nicer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, okay.  Here it comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here what comes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The extortion, the threats ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't gonna --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I can always find someplace else to work. Someplace that'll pay me a fortune and give me a view of the French Riviera ..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed, I swear, I'm not --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, fine.  Fine  You backed me into a corner again.  You're holding me hostage ... He reaches into his breast pocket, pulls out a check.  Ha it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it. Erin does.  Looks at it.  Her eyes bug out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two million dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The firm took in sixty.  That's three percent.  Seemed like a fair bonus to me. She stares at it, speechless.  He goes back to unpacking

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, now I suppose you're gonna say it's not enough.  Well, tough, Erin.  Too goddamn bad.  Cause this is absolutely, positively where I draw the line.
